Sec. 2-14. - Justices of the peace. 
    There shall be thirty (30) justices of the peace in the city. Two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the total number of justices shall be selected equally according to the provisions of the Connecticut General Statutes from the political parties qualifying as major parties under the required provisions of the Connecticut General Statutes. The remaining one-third ( 1/3 ) of the total number of justices shall be selected according to the provisions of the Connecticut General Statutes from those persons who are not members of political parties which qualify as major parties under the required provisions of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 697, 5-9-96) 
Sec. 2-15. - Agricultural land preservation fund. 
(a)  Establishment of fund. There is hereby established the Shelton Agricultural Land Preservation Fund. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words shall have the following meaning for purposes of this section: 
    Agricultural land means any land in the city suitable by reference to soil types, existing and past use of such land for agricultural purposes and other relevant factors for the cultivation of plants for production of human food and fiber or production of other useful and valuable plant products and for production of animals, livestock and poultry useful to man and the environment, and land capable of providing economically profitable farm units, and may include adjacent pastures, wood land, natural drainage areas and other adjacent open areas. 
    City means the City of Shelton. 
    Conservation commission means the conservation commission of the city. 
    Development rights means the rights of the fee simple owner of agricultural land to develop, construct on, sell, lease or otherwise improve the agricultural land for uses that result in rendering such land no longer agricultural land, but shall not be construed to include: 
(1)  The uses defined in subsection (g) of Section 1-1 of the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended by Section 1 of the Public Act 83-587; 
(2)  The rights of the fee owner of agricultural land to develop, construct on, sell the property in its entirety, lease or otherwise improve the agricultural land to preserve, maintain, operate or continue such land as agricultural land, including but not limited to, construction thereon of residences for persons directly incidental to farm operation and buildings for animals, roadside stands and farm markets for sale to the consumer of food products and ornamental plants, facilities for the storing of equipment and products or processing thereof of such other improvements, activities and uses thereon as may be directly or incidentally related to the operation of the agricultural enterprise, as long as the acreage and productivity of arable land for crops is not materially deceased and due consideration is given to the impact of any decrease in acreage or productivity of such arable land upon the total farm operation, except that new construction or modification of an existing farm building necessary to the operation of a farm on prime farmland, as defined by the United States Department of Agriculture, of which the city has purchased development rights shall be limited to not more than five (5) percent of the total of such prime farm land; 
(3)  The rights of the fee owner to provide for the extraction of gravel or like natural elements for purposes directly or incidentally related to the operation of the agricultural enterprise; or 
(4)  The existing water and mineral rights, exclusive of gravel, of the fee owner. 
    Fund means the Open Space Trust In Agency Account. 
(c)  Source of the fund. There shall be deposited in and become part of the fund all monies received by the city from whatever sources and by whatever means (a) as gifts for agricultural land preservation purposes; (b) as grants or loans for agricultural land preservation purposes; and (c) as appropriations by the city. 
(d)  Use of the fund. Upon review by the conservation commission and approval by the board of aldermen, such amounts in the fund as may be approved by the board of aldermen may be used for the acquisition in the name of the city of development rights of agricultural land, provided that the development rights have been voluntarily offered for sale to the city by the owner; and the land has been designated for preservation purposes as shown on the farm land priority map of the city open space plan. In addition, the fund may be used for any expenditure incurred in the preservation of agricultural land, subject to the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(e)  Joint acquisition procedures. The conservation commission shall follow procedures for joint acquisition of the development rights to agricultural land by the city and the state in accordance with the regulations adopted by the commissioner of agriculture. 
(f)  Custody and investment of the funds. The fund shall be in the custody of the city treasurer or other officer in charge of funds for the city. All or part of the fund may from time to time be invested in any securities in which public funds may be lawfully invested. All income derived from such investments shall be paid into the fund and become a part thereof. All monies so invested shall at times be subject to withdrawal from such investment for use as provided in subsection (d). 
(g)  Annual reports. Annually, the city treasurer or other officer having custody of the fund shall submit to the city meeting a complete and detailed report of the condition of the fund, which report shall be made a part of the annual city report. 
(h)  Negotiator. The mayor, or his designee or designees, shall have the authority to negotiate to purchase development rights from an owner of agricultural land. 
(Ord. No. 701, §§ 1-8, 6-13-96) 
Sec. 2-16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 769, adopted Feb. 13, 2003, repealed § 2-16, which pertained to violations relating to city property open to the public, and derived from Ord. No. 711, adopted March 13, 1997. Similar provisions can be found at §§ 11-51 and 11-52. 
Sec. 2-17. - Returned check fee. 
    Anyone who issues a check to the City of Shelton that is returned for any reason, including insufficient funds, closed account, payment stopped, etc., will be assessed a twenty dollar ($20.00) service fee. 
(Ord. No. 736, 6-10-99) 
Sec. 2-18. - Procedure to sell city property. 
(a)  Definition. From time to time the city may be asked or may decide to sell real property owned by the city and hereby determines that a procedure shall be provided regarding the sale of said real property. Said procedure pertains only to property which the board of aldermen considers "significant". 
    "Significant" shall be defined as the sale of real property which has a fair market value in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(b)  Initial determination by the board. 
(1)  If a request is received by the board of aldermen requesting the city to sell city owned real property and the board of aldermen determines that the board has an interest in selling said property or if the board of aldermen decides to sell city owned real property, the procedure set forth in subsection (c) shall be followed. 
(2)  The administrative assistant or his/her designee shall administer this procedure. 
(c)  Procedure. 
(1)  The board of aldermen shall request from the conservation commission and parks and recreation commission their written opinion regarding said sale. 
(2)  The administrative assistant or his/her designee will request an 8-24 referral from the planning and zoning commission. 
a.  If the 8-24 is favorable to sell, the process will continue. 
b.  If the 8-24 is unfavorable, the board of aldermen must override the unfavorable by a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote in order to proceed. 
(3)  A property appraisal shall be secured by the administrative assistant or his/her designee. Any appraisal received shall not be disclosed publicly until after the sale has been completed. 
(4)  The board of aldermen shall hold a public hearing in accordance with P.A. 07-218, when applicable. Following the public hearing, a special meeting will be held to consider and decide if the board of aldermen wishes to proceed with the sale process. 
(5)  The next step is to advertise that the city is accepting bids with a cutoff date to receive sealed bids subject to any deed restrictions and/or conditions the board deems appropriate. Each bid must be accompanied with a check equal to ten (10) percent of the amount bid. 
(6)  The purchasing agent would publicly open the bids and determines the highest, responsible bidder. The board of aldermen reserves the right to reject any and all bids. 
(7)  The board of aldermen considers the bids and votes to accept or reject. 
Note: Specifically excluded from this process is the sale of real property located within the redevelopment plan or a municipal development plan as designated by the board of aldermen and any other parcel of real estate not within said plan but determined by the board of aldermen to be within the city's best interest to exclude such parcel from said process. The board of aldermen shall determine the process of the sale of real property located within a redevelopment plan or a municipal redevelopment plan on a case by case basis taking into consideration any grant and statutory requirements and with regard to other parcels so excluded. The board of aldermen shall determine the process of the sale of real property on a case by case basis taking into consideration the most practical and reasonable process for disposition. 
(Ord. No. 782, 7-8-04; Ord. No. 832, 10-11-07; Ord. No. 839, 2-11-09; Ord. No. 853, 7-8-10; Ord. No. 885, 2-11-15) 
Secs. 2-19-2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF ALDERMEN[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Board of aldermen, Ch. 4. 

Sec. 2-26. - Regular meetings. 
    The regular meetings of the board of aldermen shall be held on the second Thursday of each month, in the council chamber in the city hall, or at such place as may be agreed upon by the board of aldermen, at a time to be agreed upon by the board of aldermen. In the event that such a meeting night falls on a legal holiday, then that regular meeting shall be held on a date, time, and place to be agreed upon by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 388, § 1(a), 1-10-80; Ord. No. 762, § 1, 4-11-02) 
Charter reference- Meetings, § 4.3. 
Sec. 2-27. - Special meetings. 
    Special meetings of the board of aldermen may be called by the mayor at any time by giving to each alderman written or verbal notice of the usual place of abode of the aldermen, but any meeting of the board of aldermen at which the mayor and all the aldermen are present shall be a legal meeting. 
(Comp. Ords. 1975, § 1.1(1)) 
Sec. 2-28. - Order of business at meetings. 
(a)  The order of business at all regular meeting of the board of aldermen, unless dispensed with by unanimous consent, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Pledge of allegiance; 
(2)  Reading of the minutes of the special and last regular meetings; 
(3)  Reports of committees; 
(4)  Unfinished business; 
(5)  New business. 
(b)  All meetings of all boards and commissions shall be conducted under and governed by parliamentary procedure as defined by Robert's Rules of Order. 
(Comp. Ords. 1975, § 1.1 (3)) 
Sec. 2-29. - Appointment of committees, boards and commissions. 
(a)  The president of the board of aldermen, within thirty (30) days after assuming the duties of his position, shall appoint from the board of aldermen the following committees, boards or commissions, or whatever other committees, boards or commissions he or she shall deem necessary: 
(1)  Finance committee (claims, abatements); 
(2)  Public health and safety (lights, sewers, police, fire); 
(3)  Street committee. 
(b)  Each of the above-mentioned committees, boards or commissions, or whatever other committees, boards or commissions shall be deemed necessary, shall consist of no more than four (4) aldermen, one (1) of whom shall be designated by the president of the board of aldermen as chairman, and they shall hold office until removed therefrom by the president of the board of aldermen or a majority of the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 309, 4-10-78; Ord. No. 388, §§ 1, 2, 1-10-80; Ord. No. 762, § 2, 4-11-02) 
Charter reference- Boards, commissions and other bodies appointed by the board of aldermen, § 5.3. 
Secs. 2-30-2-40. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-41. - Voiding of tape recordings of public meetings of boards and commissions. 
    All tape recordings of public meetings held by the various boards and commissions of the city can be voided only one (1) year after the official typed minutes are approved by the members and the document is recorded with the city/town clerk. 
(Ord. No. 315, 5-8-78) 
Sec. 2-42. - Board of aldermen to act as municipal flood and erosion control board. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted by section 25-84 of the general statutes, the board of aldermen is empowered to act as the municipal flood and erosion control board for the city, with all of the powers as provided in sections 25-85 through 25-98, inclusive, of the general statutes. 
(Ord. No. 628, 10-10-91) 
Sec. 2-43. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 727, adopted Nov. 12, 1998, enacted provisions establishing an open space committee. The editor has treated those provisions as superseding the provisions of § 2-43 which derived from Ord. No. 631, adopted Nov. 14, 1991. The more extensive provisions of Ord. No. 727 have been codified as §§ 2-115-2-115.9. 
Sec. 2-44. - Clerk's pay. 
(a)  For any clerk hired after July 1, 2000, who performs the duties of taking and transcribing the minutes of the meetings of the various boards and commissions shall be paid at the rate of eighteen dollars ($18.00) per hour. If said clerk is the regular clerk of the board or commission and is employed by the City of Shelton in another capacity, the hours employed in both positions shall be added together to provide that said clerk be paid one and one-half (11/2) the weighted average hourly rate earned during the week for each hour worked in excess of forty (40) hours in any week. "Regular clerk" is defined as a clerk who attends and takes minutes at meetings of a board or commission on a regular basis. A clerk who attends and takes minutes of meetings on only an occasional or sporadic basis shall not be considered the regular clerk and shall not be entitled to overtime compensation as described above. "Weighted average" shall be determined in accordance with 29 C.F.R. Section 778.115. 
(b)  The hourly rate of eighteen dollars ($18.00) described in subsection (a) shall not apply to any clerk hired on or before July 1, 2000. All other provisions of said subsection (a) shall apply to all clerks regardless of the date of hire. The rate of pay for any clerk hired prior to July 1, 2000, shall continue to be paid at the rate in effect as of said date provided that if said clerk was being paid less than eighteen dollars ($18.00) per hour, said clerk's pay shall be increased to eighteen dollars ($18.00) per hour. 
(c)  Any clerk who attends a properly scheduled meeting which is canceled for any reason shall be paid a sum equal to two (2) hour wage. 
(d)  This section is effective May 1, 2005. 
(Ord. No. 741, 6-8-00; Ord. No. 748, 5-10-01; Ord. No. 788, 4-14-05; Ord. No. 870, 4-11-13) 
Secs. 2-45-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WAR MEMORIAL SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE[4] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 784, adopted Sept. 9, 2004, repealed §§ 2-51-2-57, which had pertained to the permanent war memorial commission, and derived from the 1975 Compilation of Ordinances and Ord. No. 318, adopted May 8, 1978. Similar provisions were enacted to read as codified in § 2-51. 

Sec. 2-51. - War memorial scholarship committee. 
(a)  The board of aldermen of the City of Shelton hereby ordains that there shall be a war memorial scholarship committee comprised of five (5) members. This committee shall review the agency funds available and annually award a scholarship(s) as determined by criteria deemed appropriate by the committee. 
(b)  The committee shall be comprised of three (3) residents of Shelton who shall have seen active military service. They shall serve staggered terms of three (3) years and may be reappointed. In addition, the city treasurer and the superintendent of schools shall serve for the duration of their election/appointment. The committee shall report their activities annually to the board of aldermen.

DIVISION 3. - ENERGY COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-66. - Established; composition; terms of members. 
    There is hereby established an energy commission and the energy commission shall be appointed by the mayor. The energy commission shall consist of not less than five (5) nor more than nine (9) members and not more than a simple majority shall be from the same political party. The members of the energy commission shall be appointed as follows: one-third ( 1/3 ) of the members shall be appointed for two (2) years; one-third ( 1/3 ) of the members shall be appointed for three (3) years; one-third ( 1/3 ) of the members shall be appointed for four (4) years. 
(Ord. No. 392, 2-14-80) 
Sec. 2-67. - Selection of officers; permanent meeting night. 
    At the first meeting of the energy commission the members shall select a chairman, vice-chairman and a secretary. They shall also set a permanent meeting night. 
(Ord. No. 392, 2-14-80) 
Sec. 2-68. - Purpose; duties. 
    The purpose of the energy commission shall be to investigate energy needs and usage in all municipal buildings, this includes but is not limited to schools, firehouses, the library, etc. Within seven (7) months of appointment the energy commission shall submit to the mayor an energy program with specific recommendations for all buildings surveyed. This program shall include, but is not limited to, the following information: 
(1)  A detailed energy audit of the building; 
(2)  Recommendations as to immediate ways to reduce energy consumption in the building; 
(3)  Recommendations as to capital improvements that should be made to the building or its operation that will result in long term energy conservation and reduce the overall cost of energy for the building; 
(4)  A return of investment schedule that shows approximate time tables for the above described programs. 
(Ord. No. 392, 2-14-80) 
Sec. 2-69. - Reports. 
    The energy commission shall from time to time, but not less than quarterly, submit reports to the mayor as to the progress being made in an effort to reduce the overall cost and usage of energy by the city. The energy commission shall also recommend alternative sources or uses of energy in all municipal buildings. 
(Ord. No. 392, 2-14-80) 
Secs. 2-70-2-80. - Reserved.

DIVISION 6. - SENIOR CITIZENS COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-106. - Created; purpose. 
    Pursuant to section 7-148 of the general statutes there is hereby created a senior citizens committee to study the needs of and coordinate programs for the aged. 
(Comp. Ords. 1975, § 2.6) 
Sec. 2-107. - Composition; terms of members; political affiliation. 
    The senior citizens committee shall consist of nine (9) members who shall be appointed by the mayor and hold office for two (2) years from the dates of their appointment. No more than a simple majority of the senior citizen committee shall be from any single political party. 
(Comp. Ords. 1975, § 2.6; Ord. No. 509, § 1, 10-9-86) 
Sec. 2-108. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the senior citizens committee shall be filled by appointment by the mayor. 
(Comp. Ords. 1975, § 2.6; Ord. No. 509, § 1, 10-9-86) 
Sec. 2-109. - Ex officio members. 
    The health officer, welfare commissioner and state representative or representatives shall be ex officio members of the senior citizens committee. 
(Ord. No. 104, 9-8-69; Ord. No. 509, § 1, 10-9-86) 
Sec. 2-110. - Senior citizens center director. 
(a)  The senior citizens committee may retain a full-time salaried director, senior citizens center, of programs for the aging whose general duties shall be to coordinate programs for the aging and to assist the senior citizens committee in its study of the needs of the aging, as more fully set forth in section 2-193 (Ordinance No. 218, dated June 10, 1974). 
(b)  The director of the senior citizens center, shall be hired by the mayor subject to the approval of the board of aldermen upon the recommendation of the senior citizens committee. 
(c)  The director shall be subject to the procedures set forth in the merit system ordinance dated March 10, 1983 as amended. 
(Ord. No. 108, §§ a-c, 3-9-70; Ord. No. 353, 10-16-78; Ord. No. 509, § 1, 10-9-86) 
Sec. 2-111. - Municipal agent for the elderly; appointment, duties, term. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 7-127-b of the general statutes the mayor shall also appoint a municipal agent for the elderly. 
(b)  The municipal agent shall either be: 
(1)  A member of the senior citizens commission; or 
(2)  An elected official of the city; or 
(3)  A responsible resident of the city who has demonstrated an interest in the elderly or has been involved in programs in the field of the aging. 
(4)  A member of another agency that serves elderly persons. 
(c)  The duties of the municipal agent shall include but not be limited to: 
(1)  Dissemination of information to the elderly and assistance to them relative to community resources available to them; 
(2)  Publication of resources and benefits available to the elderly; 
(3)  Assist elderly in applying for federal benefits and other benefits available to such individuals; 
(4)  Submit a written report at least annually to the mayor, the board of aldermen and the senior citizen commission and a copy to the state department on the aging relative to the services such agent has provided, the needs and problems of the elderly and any recommendations to the city for proposed action with regard to elderly persons. 
(d)  The agent shall serve for a term of two (2) years and may be reappointed. The mayor shall have the power to remove any such appointee. 
(e)  The mayor may also appoint one (1) or more assistant agents as he deems necessary. 
(f)  The city/town clerk shall notify the state department of aging immediately of the appointment of a new municipal agent. 
(Ord. No. 509, § 2, 10-9-86) 
DIVISION 7. - YOUTH SERVICE BUREAU 

Sec. 2-112. - Created. 
    Pursuant to section 10-19m et seq. of the Connecticut General Statutes, the city hereby creates a youth service bureau to evaluate, plan, coordinate and implement prevention, intervention and treatment services for delinquent, pregnant, parenting and troubled youth. Said youth may be referred to the bureau by schools, police, juvenile courts, local youth serving agencies, parents or by self referral. The youth service bureau will offer skill building opportunities, educational programs and recreational activities to all youth in the city in order to encourage them to develop positively and to function as responsible members of the community. 
(Ord. No. 549, 5-12-88; Ord. No. 772, 7-3-03; Ord. No. 881, 8-14-14) 
Sec. 2-113. - Members; terms. 
    The advisory board for the city youth service bureau shall consist of twenty two (22) members who shall be appointed by the mayor and hold office for two (2) years from the dates of their appointment. No more than a simple majority of the board shall be from any single political party. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment by the mayor. The mayor, police chief and superintendent of schools or their designee shall be "ex-officio" members of the advisory board. Appointments shall be made in compliance with the requirements of section 10-19m-2 of the Connecticut General Statutes, as same may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 772, 7-3-03; Ord. No. 881, 8-14-14) 
Sec. 2-113.1. - Director. 
    The youth service bureau shall have a director whom shall perform duties as determined by the mayor or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 1(A), 5-12-88; Ord. No. 772, § 1(A), 7-3-03; Ord. No. 881, 8-14-14) 
Sec. 2-113.2. - Purpose; services provided. 
(a)  The purpose of the youth service bureau shall include but not be limited to providing the following services: 
(1)  Advocacy for youth and families. 
(2)  Crisis intervention and referrals. 
(3)  Parent education. 
(4)  Recreational and educational programs. 
(5)  Substance abuse prevention education. 
(6)  Outreach programs to insure participation and planning by the community for the development of a variety of programs and services for youth and families. 
(7)  Peer education and peer mentoring programs. 
(8)  Juvenile review board to offer diversion from juvenile court for first time offenders age eighteen (18) and younger who admit guilt. 
(b)  The services to be provided by the youth service bureau are intended to address the needs of all city youth and their families. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 1(B), (C), 5-12-88; Ord. No. 772, § 1(B), (C), 7-3-03; Ord. No. 881, 8-14-14) 
Sec. 2-113.3. - Compliance with regulations. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 10-19m of the Connecticut General Statutes, the youth service bureau shall comply with the regulations adopted by the state department of education. 
(b)  The bureau shall adopt other rules and regulations as deemed necessary to accomplish the purposes set forth in this division and to comply with the statutory requirements and the regulations adopted by the commissioner of education regarding youth service bureaus, as same may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 2, 5-12-88; Ord. No. 772, § 2, 7-3-03; Ord. No. 881, 8-14-14) 
Sec. 2-113.4. - Contract with community alert program. 
    Community alert program is now part of the youth service bureau with their own line item in the YSB budget. We no longer contract with them. 
(Ord. No. 633, 3-12-92; Ord. No. 881, 8-14-14) 
DIVISION 8. - COMMISSION ON DISABILITIES 

Sec. 2-114. - Established. 
    There shall be a commission on disabilities established in compliance with and pursuant to the Americans with Disabilities Act as of July 26th, 1990. 
(Ord. No. 646, 6-11-92) 
Sec. 2-114.1. - Composition. 
    The commission shall be composed of one (1) elected, one (1) educator, one (1) person from the health/medical profession, one (1) person from the business community and three (3) from the disabled community. These persons shall select a chairman of the commission from the appointed body. 
(Ord. No. 646, 6-11-92) 
Sec. 2-114.2. - Appointments; terms of members. 
    Appointments shall be made by the board of aldermen. Four (4) members shall serve for two-year terms and three (3) members shall be elected for an initial one-year term. Subsequent appointments shall be for two-year terms. Members may be reappointed. 
(Ord. No. 646, 6-11-92) 
Sec. 2-114.3. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The commission shall hear complaints regarding access or alleged discrimination that have not been satisfactorily resolved by the designated Municipal Americans with Disabilities Act Coordinator. 
    The commission shall be charged with establishing procedures for hearing complaints of noncompliance and receiving requests or suggestions from persons with disabilities regarding access to and participation in public facilities, services, activities and functions offered to the general public. Any action taken by this commission shall be in compliance with applicable state and federal statutes. 
(Ord. No. 646, 6-11-92) 
DIVISION 9. - OPEN SPACE COMMITTEE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 802, adopted Sept. 14, 2006, is being treated as superceding provisions pertaining to the same subject matter and previously codified as §§ 2-115-2-115.9. Former §§ 2-115-2-115.9 had derived from Ord. No. 727, adopted Nov. 12, 1998; and Ord. No. 735, adopted March 3, 1999. 
Cross reference- Open space regulations, § 11-51. 

Sec. 2-115. - Established. 
    The City of Shelton shall establish an open space program and an open space trust account to provide for the funding of such in accordance with the terms, limitations and conditions as follows. 
(Ord. No. 802, 9-14-06) 
Sec. 2-115.1. - Open space. 
    "Open space" shall be defined as designated areas deemed necessary or desirable for the preservation of the city's natural resources. Such areas shall emphasize active and passive recreation sites, natural resource protection areas such as rare or endangered habitat, areas related to public health and safety including floodplain, wetlands, unbuildable areas or areas with limitations for development and areas that shape community design such as greenbelts and buffer strips. Particular attention should be paid, but not limited, to farmlands, forestlands, riverfront lands, coastal area management zones, reservoirs and aquifers. 
(Ord. No. 802, § 1, 9-14-06) 
Sec. 2-115.2. - Establishment of trust account. 
    Within sixty (60) days of the installation of the first committee and upon receipt of the first annual appropriation of funds, the finance director shall establish an interest bearing account and insert a line item account in the budget to be used for the deposit of the first and all subsequent appropriations mandated by this division and any other funding the committee may receive from additional sources. Use of the trust account shall be by recommendation of the conservation commission. Monies accrued in the trust account shall be used for open space needs such as the identification, determination of suitability, purchase of land, title searches, appraisals, title insurance, etc in conjunction with the open space program. Funds may also be used for administrative expenses related to the operation of the committee and the development of plans regarding the desirability and use of lands designated open space. The conservation commission shall annually prepare a fiscal report to be submitted to the board of aldermen no later than March 1. 
(Ord. No. 802, § 2, 9-14-06) 
Sec. 2-115.3. - Appropriation of funds. 
    Commencing with fiscal year 2012-2013 and each fiscal year thereafter, the board of aldermen shall allocate a sum of money which is the lesser of the monies expended from the open space trust account in the previous fiscal year or fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) from the annual budget to the open space trust account which sum should be appropriated within forty-five (45) days of the commencement of the fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 802, § 3, 9-14-06; Ord. No. 871, 4-11-13) 
Sec. 2-115.4. - Plan of intent. 
    The conservation commission will assume the open space committee functions regarding preparations and updating of a general plan to ensure continued success of the city open space program. These functions should include, but not be limited to, identifying areas of need, intended or possible uses, estimated costs of acquisitions and the general costs of the types of lands desired, as well as an estimation of how much land the city would need to obtain, which, when combined with existing properties and areas designated as open space, would satisfy the need for a comprehensive open space and conservation program. This plan should also incorporate a breakdown of the needs and possibilities in order to insure a fair distribution of the city's open space resources. The committee is encouraged to avail themselves of the cooperation of any city board, commission or agency and to make full use of any and all studies, plans or information legally available from any source which may be pertinent to the formulation of this plan. No expenditure of funds from the trust account shall occur before this plan is accepted and approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 802, § 4, 9-14-06) 
Sec. 2-115.5. - Grants and matching funds. 
    The committee shall actively seek and apply for any available grants, matching funds, gifts, bequests and any other possible sources of land and revenue in order to fulfill the goals of this ordinance. The committee shall seek and identify possible sources of revenue which would be beneficial to the conservation and maintenance of the open space property. 
(Ord. No. 802, § 5, 9-14-06) 
Sec. 2-115.6. - Expenditure of funds. 
    The board of aldermen shall have sole authority over the means of expenditures, including, but not limited to, any bonding or financing needed for the acquisition of property. No expenditure shall be made from the trust account established by this division except by vote of the board of aldermen in accordance with section 4.3.2 of the City Charter. All property and open spaces acquired by the City of Shelton pursuant to this division shall be used whether for open space purposes or other municipal purposes as directed by the board of aldermen, with recommendation from the conservation commission. 
(Ord. No. 802, § 6, 9-14-06) 
Sec. 2-115.7. - Duration of division provisions. 
    This division shall expire when the city has designated as "permanent open space" fifteen (15) percent, or such other goal as determined by the board of aldermen (BOA), of its total land area as "open space." If land originally purchased and designated as "open space" is then utilized for purposes not defined as "open space," these properties will no longer be considered to fulfill the targeted fifteen (15) percent and will be replaced with land of equal quality in the same geographical area, whenever possible. Despite reaching its targeted "open space" acquisition goal, the BOA may continue this and any other pertinent "open space" ordinances, all committees involved in the "open space" program and the open space trust account as it deems appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 802, § 7, 9-14-06) 
Sec. 2-115.8. - Source of division provisions. 
    The above division is a compilation of Ordinance No. 249 adopted on August 11, 1975; Ordinance No. 631 adopted on November 14, 1991; Ordinance No. 638 adopted on April 9, 1992; Ordinance No. 700 adopted on June 13, 1996; Ordinance No. 727 adopted on November 12, 1998; and Ordinance No. 735 adopted on March 3, 1999. All monies currently held in trust for these ordinances shall become part of the open space trust account. 
(Ord. No. 802, § 8, 9-14-06) 
DIVISION 10. - VALLEY REGIONAL PLANNING AGENCY 

Sec. 2-116. - Representation. 
(a)  The City of Shelton hereby adopts the provisions of Sections 8-31a through 8-37a of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(b)  Representatives to said commission shall be electors of the City of Shelton and shall be appointed as follows: 
(1)  One (1) representative shall be appointed by the planning and zoning commission pursuant to Section 8-31a. 
(2)  One (1) representative shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(3)  One (1) representative shall be appointed by the board of aldermen. 
(c)  Each representative shall serve for a term of two (2) years from the date of appointment and until his or her successor is appointed. 
(d)  Vacancies created by the resignation or inability to serve shall be filled by the appointing authority for the remainder of the unexpired term. Any representative who is absent from three (3) consecutive regular meetings of the regional planning agency and any intervening duly called special meetings thereof shall be considered to have resigned from said body except that the requirements of this section may be waived by the board of aldermen for good cause. 
(e)  This section shall become effective on January 5, 1999. 
(Ord. No. 730, §§ 1-5, 12-10-98) 
DIVISION 11. - TOWER COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-116.1. - Created. 
    The city shall have a tower committee consisting of five (5) members, no more than three (3) of whom shall be from the same political party, appointed by the mayor to serve for staggered terms of three (3) years. The terms of two (2) members shall expire in the first and second years of a three-year cycle and the terms of one (1) member shall expire in the third year of a three-year cycle. 
(Ord. No. 759, 12-13-01) 
Sec. 2-116.2. - Duties. 
    Upon being consulted upon an application pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes, section 16-50L(e), the mayor shall refer the application to the tower committee which shall review the application and within fifteen (15) days of such referral shall issue an advisory opinion to the mayor and the board of aldermen. 
    The mayor and the board of aldermen shall take such action as is permitted and/or required by said section, and thereafter, but not later than sixty (60) days from the date of the initial consultation with the mayor to render a recommendation to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 759, 12-13-01) 
DIVISION 12. - HOUSATONIC RIVER ESTUARY COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-116.3. - Created; organization; funding. 
    The City of Shelton shall have a Housatonic River Estuary Commission consisting of seven (7) members; one (1) member from Shelton, Derby, Ansonia, Orange, Stratford, and Milford and a member-at-large. A member shall be appointed by the chief elected official and shall serve for two (2) years. The chief elected official of each town or city shall fill their vacancy as it may occur. The other six (6) members shall choose the member-at-large. The commission may employ expert and such other assistants as it judges necessary and may accept funds from any source. Notwithstanding any other provision of the Connecticut General Statutes, funds appropriated to the commission, or received by the commission from any other source, shall be held in the custody of the commission and expended by the commission for the purposes set forth in section 25-170(b) of the Connecticut General Statues, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 825, 5-10-07) 
Sec. 2-116.4. - Duties. 
    The commission may study any issues relating to the Housatonic River and may make such recommendations as may be necessary to maintain, protect and restore the resources of the estuary of the Housatonic River. The commission shall consider the adverse impact any action proposed in or for the Housatonic River estuary may have upon the marine resources of said river. The commission may prepare and submit reports to the local legislative bodies of the towns represented on said commission. 
(Ord. No. 825, 5-10-07) 
Secs. 2-116.5-2.115.10. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - PENSION BOARD 

Sec. 2-116.11. - Pension board. 
(a)  The pension board shall consist of five (5) voting members, who shall be the following: the mayor, the finance director and three (3) members shall be appointed by the mayor which members have experience in financial services and pensions. Such members appointed by the mayor shall serve for terms of two (2) years. 
(b)  All action taken by the pension board shall be by majority vote. 
(c)  The pension board members shall serve without compensation and shall have charge of the general direction and management of the pension and retirement funds managed by the city. The city shall furnish such advisors, brokers, clerical, legal, or actuarial as the pension board members shall consider necessary to carry out the purpose of this article, subject to such appropriations as shall be made in the manner provided for other city appropriations. 
(Ord. No. 878, 3-13-14) 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-117-2-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MAYOR[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- Mayor, Ch. 3. 

Sec. 2-121. - Salary; benefits. 
(a)  The office of the mayor shall be considered a full time position equivalent to "exempt" status as described in the Fair Labor Standards Act. 
(b)  An annual salary of one hundred nineteen thousand one hundred seventy six dollars ($119,176.00) shall be established for the position of mayor as of November 17, 2015 to November 22, 2016; one hundred twenty nine thousand two hundred ninety three dollars ($129,293.00) for the period November 23, 2016 to November 21, 2017 and one hundred thirty five thousand six hundred fifty nine dollars ($135,659.00) commencing November 22, 2017. Thereafter, such salary shall be adjusted each year during the third week of November based upon a cost of living adjustment as determined by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers (CPI-W). 
(c)  The mayor's salary shall be updated in November 2021 and every six (6) years thereafter by conducting a survey using the rationale employed by the city wage and salary consultant, using the latest Connecticut Conference of Municipalities (CCM) Salary Survey data among cities of like population groupings. Further, that the consultant compares ability to pay, grand list equalization and internal salary comparison data to arrive at a recommended salary. 
(d)  The objectivity in the process shall be achieved by acceptance of the fact that this process is not a science. It is logic applied by a professional wage and salary consultant who will recommend to be the board of aldermen. The board will then codify this recommendation in ordinance form, hold a public hearing on such ordinance change and then adopt the final mayoral salary. 
(e)  The mayor shall be provided with life, medical, dental, and disability insurance. Life insurance coverage will be two (2) times salary rounded to the next highest full one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), if necessary. Accidental death and dismemberment coverage equal to the amount of life insurance shall be provided. Medical, dental and disability insurance shall be provided equal to the plan being offered to merit system employees. Mayoral contributions to these plans will be equal to the contribution rate established for merit system employees. Holidays, vacation and bereavement shall be provided equal to that provided to merit system employees. The mayor shall, as a pension benefit, be entitled to a city-paid eight (8) percent of the annual base salary contribution to a 401K, or similar type plan, designated by the mayor. 
(f)  If the mayor has not received a city vehicle, the mayor shall designate his personal vehicle and be permitted to use the city gasoline supplies. 
(Ord. No. 479, 5-9-85; Ord. No. 564, 1-12-89; Ord. No. 739, §§ (1)-(5), 10-14-99; Ord. No. 758, §§ 1-5, 9-13-01; Ord. No. 790, § 2, 4-14-05; Ord. No. 828, 6-12-07; Ord. No. 884, 2-11-15) 
Cross reference- Any ordinance setting salaries for merit or nonmerit positions saved from repeal, § 1-12(11). 
Secs. 2-122-2-130. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-131. - Salary. 
    The city treasurer's salary shall be ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per year effective following the city election of November 5, 1985. 
(Ord. No. 418, 9-10-81; Ord. No. 439, 3-10-83; Ord. No. 487, 10-10-85; Ord. No. 738, 10-14-99)

DIVISION 4. - CORPORATION COUNSEL[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 669, adopted April 14, 1994, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion as § 2-134 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-134. - Salary. 
a)  Commencing July 1, 2016 the annual compensation for general matters for the Corporation Counsel shall be $48,746.00 to be paid in monthly increments during the fiscal year. The salary for the Assistant Corporation Counsel shall be $34,093.00 payable in monthly increments during the fiscal year. 
b)  The Corporation Counsel shall receive, in addition to such sum, the sum of $764.00 per month in lieu of secretarial assistance and the Assistant Corporation Counsel shall receive a payment of $622.00 per month in lieu of secretarial assistance. 
c)  For those matters which are not included within the above referenced items of compensation, specifically litigation, contested matters and labor work and such other matters as historically have not been included within the annual compensation of the Corporation Counsel, the hourly rate shall be approved by the Board of Aldermen from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 669, 4-14-94; Ord. No. 724, §§ 1-3, 5-14-98; Ord. No. 760, 4-11-02; Ord. No. 789, §§ 1, 2, 4-14-05; Ord. No. 836, 3-13-08; Ord. No. 863, 3-8-12; Ord. No. 898, 6-9-16) 
Sec. 2-135. - Appointment of special counsel. 
    If, in the opinion of the corporation counsel, corporation counsel or the assistant corporation counsel is unable to represent any commission, board, agency or an individual acting in his/ her official capacity for any reason and said commission, board, agency or individual acting in his/her official capacity entitled to legal representation pursuant to law, the mayor, with the approval of the board of aldermen, shall hire special counsel to represent said commission, board, agency or individual acting in his/her official city capacity. The mayor shall endeavor to retain such counsel at an hourly rate equivalent to that which is being paid to the corporation counsel for litigation matters, but if the mayor is unable to retain counsel at such rate, she/he shall retain such counsel at a reasonable rate under all of the circumstances, with the approval of the board of aldermen, provided that there are sufficient funds in the legal services budget to cover such fees. No commission, board, agency or individual acting in his/her official capacity may retain or hire legal counsel without the prior consent of the mayor and the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 767, 7-11-02) 
Secs. 2-136-2-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PERSONNEL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-141. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 695, adopted April 11, 1996, repealed Ord. No. 482, adopted Sept. 12, 1985 from which § 2-141 derived. Section 2-141 pertained to insurance benefits. 
Sec. 2-142. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 695, adopted April 11, 1996, repealed Ord. No. 423, adopted Dec. 10, 1981 from which § 2-142 derived. Section 2-142 pertained to a dental plan. 
Sec. 2-143. - Retirement plan. 
(a)  There is hereby established a municipal employee retirement plan for the city. 
(b)  Each municipal employee and each nonprofessional employee of the board of education on the date of enactment of the ordinance from which this section derives who is not now covered by an existing pension plan of any nature and not receiving any pension by reason of any special act of the legislature, shall upon reaching the age of sixty-five (65) years be entitled to a pension from the city of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year commencing at the termination of his employment provided that upon reaching the age of sixty-five (65) years, he shall have completed twenty (20) consecutive years as a full-time regular employee of the city or of the board of education. 
(c)  Any such employee having served twenty (20) consecutive years and, who, upon reaching age sixty (60), is unable, for physical reasons as determined by a doctor chosen by the city, to fulfill the duties of his position, shall be entitled to a pension of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year provided, however, that this section shall not apply if the person is receiving any other payment or benefits directly or indirectly from the city or from workmen's compensation. 
(d)  If any person who is receiving a pension dies leaving a widow of the age of sixty-five (65) or over, then the pension shall be paid to such widow as long as she shall live and shall remain unmarried. 
(e)  The board of apportionment and taxation shall each year appropriate sufficient funds to pay the pension of the persons entitled thereto under the provisions of this section. 
(f)  The city has the right to alter and amend this section from time to time without the consent of the beneficiaries, provided that benefits of persons receiving pensions at the time of alteration or amendment, shall not be reduced below those specified therein. 
(g)  Nothing contained herein shall prevent the city from requiring an employee contribution as a condition of future increase benefits if it so chooses. 
(h)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section the clerk of the assessors shall be entitled to the following pension benefits upon reaching the age of sixty-five (65) years and after having completed fifteen (15) consecutive years in such position: The annual sum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) payable in equal monthly installments commencing thirty (30) days after retirement. 
(i)  Blue Cross and CMS or other medical benefits paid by the city during the employee's working years shall be continued at the expense of the city. 
(j)  Any group life insurance paid by the city during the employee's working years shall be continued at the expense of the city. 
(k)  Upon the death of such employee any surviving widow shall be entitled to receive the benefits provided in subsection (d) of this section. 
(l)  The foregoing provisions of this section to the contrary notwithstanding, any person who has held the office of chief of police of not less than four and one-half (41/2) years, pursuant to a written contract with the city as a merit system employee, and who has a minimum of twenty-five (25) years of service with the Shelton Police Department shall, in addition to any pension or other benefits which he may otherwise receive, be entitled to the following pension benefits: 
(1)  The sum of four hundred dollars ($400.00) per month from the date of retirement for a period of fifteen (15) years, or until death, whichever is sooner. 
(2)  A continuation of medical coverage for the chief of police and spouse as may be approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Comp. Ords. 1975, § 19.6; Ord. No. 722, 2-26-98) 
Sec. 2-144. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 668, adopted September 9, 1993, repealed Ord. No. 586, adopted November 8, 1990 from which § 2-144 derived. Section 2-144 pertained to the merit job classification system and was amended by Ord. No. 645, adopted June 11, 1992 and Ord. No. 656, adopted June 10, 1993. 
Sec. 2-145. - Hiring of police officers. 
(a)  Hiring of probationary candidates. 
(1)  When the city determines to hire probationary candidates for the city police department, the administrative assistant shall utilize the services of a testing and measurement or selection agency, which agency and which test is in compliance with the standards of the State of Connecticut Police Officers Standards and Training Council (POSTC), and with all applicable federal and state laws, and consistent with a job description and the merit system and personnel rules of the city, in order to identify and select qualified candidates. 
(2)  The administrative assistant shall cause the position to be advertised in accordance with the provisions of the merit system. 
(3)  All applicants who have the minimum qualifications set forth in the job description shall be allowed to participate in the testing process for the position of police officer. 
(4)  Applicants must successfully pass each phase of the testing process to be allowed to continue. The testing process shall be as follows: 
a.  The "cooper standards" or other physical agility testing recognized by POSTC shall be administered by a qualified source. The candidate must pass this phase to be allowed to continue in the testing process. 
b.  A written test shall be administered by an agency in compliance with entry level testing standards as established by the State of Connecticut Police Officers Standards and Training Council (POSTC). The passing grade shall be announced no later than the commencement of the written test. The passing grade must be achieved in order to proceed with the next phase of the testing. The number of applicants that proceed to the oral examination shall be determined by the administrative assistant and the chief of police based upon the number of positions available. The minimum number of applicants that will proceed to the oral examination will be twenty-five (25) (provided there are more than twenty-five (25) qualifying applicants). 
c.  An oral examination shall be conducted by a panel that shall comply with state regulations relating to oral interviews of prospective police candidates and the requirements of the merit system. 
(5)  To the scores obtained though the written and oral testing, the following additional points shall be added: 
a.  For a minimum of two (2) years of military service with honorable discharge: Six (6) points. 
b.  For those persons who have an associate's degree: Four (4) points. 
c.  For those persons who have a bachelor's degree: Eight (8) points. 
Said college degree shall be from an accredited college or university and shall be in a subject area relevant to the knowledge, skills, and abilities required of police officers. 
d.  For those persons who have six (6) months or more experience in active law enforcement activity within the previous five (5) years: Two (2) points. 
e.  For those persons who have fluency in speaking and writing a second language identified as a language used within the population served by the city police department: Four (4) points. 
f.  For those persons who demonstrate local knowledge of the community: One (1) point. Local knowledge shall mean a familiarity with the city, its streets, its population centers, its institutions, and its emergency service response team organization. 
(6)  Upon completion of the examination process, the administrative assistant shall create a certified list pursuant to the provisions of the merit system and submit this list to the appointing authority. 
(7)  Any appointment made shall be conditional upon the applicant having completed a subsequent background investigation including a polygraph examination, psychological examination, fingerprint check, pre-employment medical and controlled substance examination in accordance with state and city requirements that may be amended from time to time and to the satisfaction of the city. 
(8)  Definitions. 
    Probationary candidate means a police officer who, having satisfied pre-employment requirements, has commenced employment with a law enforcement unit but has not satisfactorily completed the training requirements provided for in section 7-294d of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(b)  Lateral certification or comparative certification applicants. 
(1)  Lateral certification applicants and comparative certification. Applicants shall be tested separately from other applicants set forth in section 2-145. The testing process shall include both a written and oral examination that complies with entry level testing requirements of the State of Connecticut Police Officers Standards and Training Council (POSTC) as amended from time to time and with all applicable federal and state laws and which shall be consistent with the merit system and personnel rules of the city. A physical fitness agility exam may be required by the city. 
(2)  Any appointment made shall be conditional upon the applicant having completed a subsequent polygraph examination, psychological examination, fingerprint check, background investigation, pre-employment medical, physical agility (if required) and controlled substance examination in accordance with state and city requirements that may be amended from time to time and to the satisfaction of the city. 
(3)  Upon completion of the examination process, the administrative assistant shall create a certified list pursuant to the provisions of the merit system and submit this list to the appointing authority. 
(4)  Definitions. 
    Comparative certification means the certification of a candidate for a police officer position, who has served as a police officer in another state or in a law enforcement within the state that is not subject to the statutes and regulations of the police officer standards and training council. 
    Lateral certification means the certification of a currently certified state police officer to a new position as a police officer with a different law enforcement unit within the state. 
(Ord. No. 721, §§ 3-8, 4-9-98; Ord. No. 756, 8-9-01; Ord. No. 876, 2-13-14) 
Secs. 2-146-2-160. - Reserved.
