(a)  No person shall throw, scatter, spill, or place or cause to be blown, scattered, spilled, thrown, or placed, or otherwise dispose of any litter upon any public property in the City of Shelton, or upon private property in the City of Shelton not owned by him, or in the waters of the City of Shelton including, but not limited to, any public highway, public park, beach, campground, forest land, recreational area, mobile manufactured home park, highway, road, street, or alley except: (1) when such property is designated by the City of Shelton for the disposal of garbage and refuse, and such person is authorized to use such property for such purpose, (2) into a litter receptacle in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried away or deposited by the elements upon any part of said private or public property or waters. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to a fine of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00). When any such material or substances are thrown, blown, scattered, or spilled from a vehicle, the operator thereof shall be deemed prima facie to have committed such offense. 
(c)  "Litter" means any discarded, used, or unconsumed substance or waste material, whether made of aluminum, glass, plastic, rubber, paper, or other natural or synthetic material, or any combination thereof, including, but not limited to, any bottle, jar, or can, or any top, cap, or detachable tab of any bottle, jar or can any unlighted cigarette, cigar, match, or any flaming or glowing material, or any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish, grass clippings or other lawn or garden waste, newspaper, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper containers, or other packaging or construction material which has not been deposited in a litter receptacle. "Litter" also means and includes items, books, telephone books or advertising material placed, thrown or distributed on property without the prior permission of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 755, 6-14-01; Ord. No. 822, 4-12-07; Ord. No. 894, 11-12-15; Ord. No. 907, 10-12-17) 
Secs. 7-10-7-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES (EMS) COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 676, adopted July 14, 1994, amended Ord. No. 557, adopted October 13, 1988, from which Ch. 7, Art. II, §§ 7-26-7-33 was derived. The provisions of Ord. No. 676 have been included as a new Ch. 7, Art. II to read as herein set out at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-41 et seq. 

Sec. 7-26. - Purpose. 
    The emergency medical services commission (EMS) shall oversee, monitor, coordinate and regulate emergency medical services and city owned assets used in conjunction with delivery of these services for the city. Their mission shall be to deliver the highest quality, cost effective patient care to those individuals requesting or requiring emergency medical services within the city. 
(Ord. No. 676, Art. I, 7-14-94) 
Sec. 7-27. - Membership; terms. 
(a)  The emergency medical services commission shall consist of five (5) members. 
(b)  The commissioners shall be equal in rank and authority. All commissioners shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed (subject to approval of the board of aldermen) for reasonable and necessary expenses. 
(c)  The commission shall elect a chairman and vice chairman as provided by the Charter of the city. The chairman shall preside at all meetings of the EMS commission. The vice chairman shall assume the powers and duties of the chairman in the absence of the chairman. Both the chairman and the vice chairman shall have a vote in any matter before their commission. 
(d)  The original and subsequent appointments to the commission shall be made by the board of aldermen at its first regular meeting following the effective date of this article subject to confirmation by the mayor with the board able to override an unfavorable confirmation by two-thirds vote of the board. The appointments shall provide for minority representation with no more than four (4) members from one (1) party and shall be as follows: 
(1)  Two (2) persons for a term to expire on June 30, 1995. 
(2)  Three (3) persons for a term to expire on June 30, 1996. 
(3)  Thereafter, all appointments shall be for two (2) years with commissioners serving until their replacement is appointed. 
(4)  Vacancies on the commission shall be filled within sixty (60) days in the same manner used to make original appointments. 
(e)  Four (4) absences from regularly scheduled meetings by any commissioner within a twelve-month period shall be grounds for removal on the basis of good cause under the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 676, Art. II, 7-14-94) 
Sec. 7-28. - Minutes, records and reports. 
    The commission shall have a clerk who shall keep proper minutes and records of its meetings and activities. 
(Ord. No. 676, Art. III, 7-14-94) 
Sec. 7-29. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The EMS commission shall review the need for EMS services, determine the type and manner of providing such services, oversee the emergency medical services for the city and negotiate contracts with the providers. All contracts will be subject to the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(b)  The EMS commission will be responsible for preparation and submission to the finance director and the mayor an annual line item budget covering all EMS service related costs such as provider costs, EMS building costs and other EMS related expenditures. The commission shall be responsible for managing such budget, once approved. They shall have the authority to authorize payment for services rendered and shall follow the budget process required of city departments. 
(c)  The EMS commission shall establish policies and procedures for the city and its EMS providers to follow and insure compliance with all state and federal requirements. In so doing, the EMS commission shall have the authority to set standards of performance and adopt rules and regulations necessary to provide this essential public service and shall do so in a manner that allows for public comments prior to adoption. 
(d)  The EMS commission shall be responsible to insure that all providers of emergency medical services to the city coordinate their activities through the EMS commission. 
(e)  The EMS commission shall have the authority to require providers of emergency medical services within the city to appear and to answer questions before the commission relating to their training, equipment, standards, procedures and delivery of emergency medical services and any other matter relevant to the provision of such services. The commission may also require such providers to produce records, including financial records or other physical evidence relevant to such inquiry that they may require. Failure of any such provider to appear, answer such questions or produce such physical evidence shall be grounds for removal or disqualification of such provider from providing emergency medical services within the city. 
(f)  The EMS commission shall maintain a communication link with the mayor and the board of aldermen through the public health and safety committee monthly meetings and by distribution of the EMS commission meeting minutes to such parties. These actions are to be supplemented by an EMS annual report to accompany the EMS budget submission. Advisory reports may be submitted at any time the commission so determines the need or, in response to a specific request of the mayor or the board of aldermen. 
(g)  The EMS commission shall establish policies for the emergency medical services building with regard to its use and operation and shall have appropriate enforcement authority over same. 
(h)  The EMS commission shall have such further authority and duties as the board of aldermen shall designate. 
(Ord. No. 676, Art. IV, 7-14-94) 
Sec. 7-30. - Miscellaneous. 
    All prior provisions and ordinances relating to emergency medical services which are inconsistent with these provisions are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 676, Art. V, 7-14-94) 
Secs. 7-31-7-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 803, adopted Jan. 11, 2007, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as codified herein. Former Art. III pertained to the same subject matter, was comprised of §§ 7-41-7-47, and derived from Ord. No. 311, adopted May 8, 1978; Ord. No. 679, adopted Nov. 10, 1994; Ord. No. 682, adopted Feb. 9, 1995; and Ord. No. 787, adopted Nov. 10, 2004. 
State Law reference- Authority to prevent disturbing noises, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(H)(viii). 

Sec. 7-41. - General prohibition. 
(1)  No person shall make, create or maintain unreasonably loud, unnecessary or disturbing noises, as defined in this article, that effect and are a detriment to the public health, comfort, convenience, safety, welfare, peace and quiet of persons within the City of Shelton. 
(2)  No person shall cause to make, create or maintain unreasonably loud, unnecessary or disturbing noises, as defined in this article, that effect and are a detriment to the public health, comfort, convenience, safety, welfare, peace and quiet of persons within the City of Shelton. 
(3)  No person shall create, cause to be created or allow the emission of sound beyond the boundaries of their property so as to cause noise pollution as defined herein in the City of Shelton, or so as to violate any provisions of this article. 
(4)  All construction activities not specifically excluded or exempt herein which are conducted on Sundays and holidays as observed by the City of Shelton shall be required to comply with the night sound levels as same are defined by this article. 
(Ord. No. 803, § 1, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 1, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 7-42. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article, the terms below shall have the following meanings: 
    Day shall be from 7:30 a.m. to 9:00 p.m., local time. 
    Decibel shall mean a unit measuring the volume of sound, equal to twenty (20) times the logarithm to the base ten (10) of the ratio of the root mean square of the pressure of the sound measured to a reference pressure of twenty (20) micropascals. 
    Emitter shall be the person who creates, causes to be created or allows the noise. 
    L-10 shall mean the A-weighted sound level exceeded ten (10) percent of the time period during which the measurement was made. 
    L-50 shall mean the A-weighted sound level exceeded fifty (50) percent of the time period during which the measurement was made. 
    Night shall be from 9:00 p.m. until midnight, and from midnight until 7:30 a.m., local time. 
    Overall sound level shall mean the overall sound pressure level, expressed in decibels (dB), measured on a sound level meter using the C-weighting network and set to the slow response. 
    Person shall be any individual, firm, partnership, company, corporation, association trust, syndicate, agency, or other legal entity of any kind. 
    Receptor shall be the person who receives the noise impact. 
    Sound level shall mean the A-weighted sound pressure level, expressed in decibels (dBA), measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network and set to the slow response. 
    Sound level meter shall mean an instrument which includes a microphone, amplifier, RMS detector, integrator or averager, output meter and weighing networks all conforming to the requirements set forth in the American National Standards Institutes American National Standard for Sound Level Meters (ANI S1.4-1974) for a precision (type 1) sound level meter. 
(Ord. No. 803, § 2, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 2, 4-12-07) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 7-43. - Classification of noise zones. 
(a)  Noise zones within the City of Shelton shall be classified in accordance with the applicable zone for that parcel or tract of land and the surrounding parcels or tracts, as detailed by the "Standard Land Use Classification Manual of Connecticut", hereafter referred to as "SLUCONN". Noise zone specified herein shall correspond to the following zoning descriptions in the zoning regulations and zoning map of the City of Shelton. Starting times commercial and industrial zones may be flexible with approval from proper authorities but excessive noise is prohibited.

(Ord. No. 803, § 3, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 3, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 7-44. - Noise zone standards. 
(a)  No person shall emit or cause to be emitted sound exceeding the sound levels stated herein when measured at any point on a tract or parcel of land not under their ownership or control. The determination of allowable sound shall be in accordance with the following objective numerical standards for the respective noise zone classes: 
C B A-Day A-Night Class C Emitter to 70 dBA 66 dBA 61 dBA 51 dBA Class B Emitter to 62 dBA 62 dBA 55 dBA 45 dBA Class A Emitter to 62 dBA 55 dBA 55 dBA 45 dBA  
Sound levels determined by the police department or planning and zoning administrator to be in excess of these values shall constitute proof of violation of this article. 
(b)  It shall be a violation for any person to: 
(1)  Use or operate any construction equipment singly or in combination with other equipment on any construction or demolition site if such use or operation results in the emission of noise, measured at any boundary of the nearest receptor in any noise zone in excess of the values listed below: 
Maximum Level of Sound** Zone L-50 L-10 A 70 dBA 80 dBA B 75 dBA 85 dBA C 80 dBA 90 dBA ** The minimum level shall not be exceeded for longer than six (6) minutes in any one-hour period.  
(2)  Conduct a utility street work installation or repair, paving work or sewer cleaning which produces a sound level exceeding eighty (80) dBA at a distance of fifty (50) feet from the operation: 
(c)  The provisions of subsections (b)(1) and (2) above shall not apply to those construction devises commonly referred to as "impact tools", including but not limited to grinders, pile drivers, paving breakers, jack hammers, rock drills or well drilling rigs, provided that such impact tools shall have intake and exhaust mufflers recommended by the manufacturer thereof, installed and working. 
(d)  In addition to the above objective standards, no person shall emit noise exceeding an overall sound level of seventy (70) dB. 
(e)  The chief of police and planning and zoning administrator shall be responsible for developing the measurement methodology to determine compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 803, § 4, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 4, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 7-45. - Exclusions. 
    This article shall not apply to: 
(a)  Sound generated by natural phenomena, including, but not limited to, wind, storms, insects, birds, amphibious creatures and water flowing in its natural course. 
(b)  The unamplified sound of the human voice. 
(c)  The unamplified sound made by wild or domestic animals. 
(d)  Sound created by bells, carillons or chimes associated with specific religious observances. 
(e)  Sound created by a public emergency sound signal attached to an authorized emergency vehicle in the immediate act of responding to an emergency, or located within or attached to a building, pole or other structure for the purpose of sounding an alarm relating to fire or civil preparedness. 
(f)  Sound created by safety and protective devices provided that such device is sounded as a warning of imminent danger or from the release of pressure buildup. 
(g)  Sound created by an intrusion alarm, provided that the emission of noise from such devices does not exceed ten (10) minutes when attached to any vehicle or thirty (30) minutes when attached to any building or structure. 
(h)  Backup alarms required by OSHA or other municipal, state or federal safety regulations. 
(i)  Farming equipment or farming activity. 
(Ord. No. 803, § 5, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 5, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 7-46. - Exemptions. 
    The following noise shall be exempted from the provisions of this article: 
(a)  Noise created by signal testing, principally siren-testing by city fire departments and civil preparedness units. 
(b)  Noise created by the regularly scheduled signaling of a specific time of day. 
(c)  Noise generated by engine-powered or motor-driven lawn care or maintenance equipment on Class "A" property between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. provided that noise discharged from exhausts is adequately muffled to prevent loud noises therefrom. 
(d)  Noises created by snow removal equipment at any time provided that noise discharged from exhausts is adequately muffled to prevent loud noises therefrom. 
(e)  Noise created by blasting provided that the blasting is conducted between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. at specified hours previously announced to the local general public or hours as determined by the fire marshal or planning and zoning commission for approved projects. 
(f)  Noise created by on-site recreational or sporting activity which is sanctioned by city government. 
(g)  Patriotic or public celebrations, such as parades, carnivals and firework displays, are exempted provided that a permit has been obtained in advance from the chief of police. 
(h)  Noise created by aircraft, or components designed for, or utilized in the development of aircraft. 
(i)  The chief of police may permit that the "day" noise standards may be applicable in industrial and commercial zones under circumstances which will not adversely effect the adjoining landowners as determined by the chief of police. 
(j)  Noise created by solid waste and recycling collection. 
(k)  Construction activities performed for nonprofit agencies or city recreational groups and/or facilities or other city purposes. 
(Ord. No. 803, § 6, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 6, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 7-47. - Prohibited noise activities. 
(a)  Vehicle horns. No person shall, at any time, sound any horn or other audible signal device of a motor vehicle unless it is necessary as a warning to prevent or avoid a traffic accident. 
(b)  Advertising. No person shall, at any time, use any drum, bell or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention to any performance, show or sale, or to the display or advertisement of merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 803, § 7, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 7, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 7-48. - Motor and recreational vehicle noise. 
(a)  All motor and recreational vehicles within the limits of the city shall be subject to the noise standards and decibel levels as found in title 14, section 14-80a of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(b)  No sound amplifying devices on or within motor vehicles shall emit noise in excess of the noise levels as specified in section 7-44. 
(Ord. No. 803, § 8, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 8, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 7-49. - Inspections. 
(a)  For the purpose of determining compliance with the provisions of this article, the chief of police or his designated representative is hereby authorized to make inspections of all noise sources and to take measurements and make tests, whenever necessary, to determine the quantity and character of noise. In the event that any person refuses or restricts entry and free access to any part of a premises, or refuses inspection, testing or noise measurement of any activity, device, facility, or process where inspection is sought, the chief of police or his designated representative may seek, from the appropriate court, a warrant, without interference, restriction or obstruction, at a reasonable time, for the purpose of inspecting, testing or measuring noise. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to allow or permit the chief of police or his designated representative free access to any premise, when the chief of police or his designated representative is acting in compliance with a warrant for inspection and order issued by the appropriate court. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of any warrant or court order requiring inspection, testing or measurement of noise sources. 
(d)  No person shall hinder, obstruct, delay, resist, prevent in any way, interfere or attempt to interfere with any authorized person while in the performance of his/her duties under this article. 
(Ord. No. 803, § 9, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 9, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 7-50. - Violations and enforcement. 
(a)  The police department under the direction of the chief of police shall be responsible for investigating complaints of noise pollution. 
(b)  The police department or planning and zoning personnel shall be responsible for making acoustic measurements to determine that a violation has in fact occurred, at the request of the chief of police or his designee. 
(c)  The chief of police shall formulate a schedule, based upon economically reasonable and technologically feasible noise control procedures, that will bring the noise emitter into compliance with this article. 
(d)  Any person violating this article shall be subject to a fine that shall be the maximum allowed by Connecticut General Statutes section 7-148 for each offense, in accordance with section 1-11 of the City Ordinances. 
(e)  Each separate instance shall be considered a separate violation 
(f)  Nothing in this article shall prevent the police department, because of the perceived nature of the offence, from proceeding not under the terms of this article, but under the provisions of Connecticut General Statutes sections 531-181, 53a-181a and 53a-182, as they may be amended from time to time, which sections relate, generally to breach of peace, creating a public disturbance, and disorderly conduct, etc. 
(Ord. No. 803, § 10, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 824, § 10, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 7-51-7-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DUST[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate the emission of smoke, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(8)(D). 

Sec. 7-61. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Dust shall mean all dust, ash, soot, fly ash, dirt or other fine particles of matter. 
    Dust-producing substance shall mean all coal, charcoal, coke, sand, gravel, dirt or any other substance composed of, mixed with, producing or otherwise capable of spreading or disseminating dust. 
(Ord. No. 132, § I, 6-12-72) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 7-62. - Coverings required when transporting dust or dust-producing substances. 
    No dust or dust-producing substance shall be transported through any street without protection and covering, at all times, sufficient effectually to prevent the spreading or dissemination of dust from such dust-producing substance into the air or upon any public or private property. Each violation thereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 132, § II, 6-12-72) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 7-63. - Responsibility of persons handling dust or dust-producing substances. 
    No person shall handle, transport, work, load, unload, trade or deal with any dust or dust-producing substance in any place in the city so as, by the dissemination of dust, to annoy or disturb unreasonably or to endanger the health of, any other person or to damage or render unsightly any property or thing. 
(Ord. No. 132, § III, 6-12-72)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Purposes. 
(a)  It is hereby declared that the purpose of this chapter is to protect, preserve, and promote the physical and mental health and social well being of the people; to regulate private and publicly owned dwellings for the purpose of maintaining adequate sanitation and public health; and to protect the safety of the people and to promote the general welfare by legislation which shall be applicable to all rental or leased dwellings now in existence or hereafter constructed. 
(b)  It is hereby further declared that the purpose of this chapter is to: 
(1)  Establish minimum standards for basic equipment and facilities for light, ventilation, heating and cooling; for safety from fire and accidents; for the use and location and amount of space for human occupancy; and for safe and sanitary maintenance; 
(2)  To determine the responsibilities of owners, operators and occupants of dwellings and commercial structures; and 
(3)  To provide for the administration and enforcement thereof. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 1.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 1.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-2. - Legislative finding. 
(a)  The enactment and enforcement of this chapter is thereby, declared to be essential to the public interest: 
(1)  To avoid premises (as defined in section 8-3) existing within the city either occupied or unoccupied by human beings, which are blighted, and such buildings or structures are blighted because of faulty design or construction, or failure to keep them in a proper state of repair, or lack of proper sanitary facilities, or lack of adequate lighting or ventilation, or the inability to properly heat, or improper management of them, or any combination of these factors, resulting in such buildings becoming so deteriorated, dilapidated, neglected, overcrowded with occupants, or so unsanitary as to jeopardize or be detrimental to the health, safety, morals or welfare to the people of the municipality; 
(2)  To further avoid that the general appearance and improper maintenance of commercial structures or commercial units which are blighted have a detrimental effect upon the property value and business activities of the entire area as well as contribute to the blighted conditions which are dangerous to the public health, safety, morals, and general welfare of the people; 
(3)  To further avoid the development of or increase in physical, mental or social ill-health or disease, mortality, crime and juvenile delinquency; 
(4)  To further avoid conditions existing on such blighted premises which are dangerous to the public health, safety, morals and general welfare of the people, and that conditions existing on such blighted premises necessitate excessive and disproportionate expenditure of public funds for public health and safety, crime prevention, fire protection and other public services, and that the conditions existing on such blighted premises cause a drain upon public revenue, impairing the efficient and economical exercise of governmental functions in such areas; 
(5)  To further the elimination of blighted premises; 
the prevention of the recurrence of blighted premises, is in the best interest of the public, and that the accomplishment of this end will be fostered and encouraged by the enactment of this chapter. 
(b)  The policy of this chapter shall be to achieve compliance with the provisions contained herein, through the cooperation of owners and occupants. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 1.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 1.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-3. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known, and may be cited, as the "Housing and Commercial Code of the City of Shelton." 
(Ord. No. 310, § 1.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 1.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-4. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter: 
    Accessory structure shall mean a structure, the use of which is incidental to that of the main building or structure, which is located on the same lot with a dwelling, or commercial structure. 
    Approved shall mean approved by the local or state authority having such administrative authority. 
    Ashes shall mean the residue from the burning of combustible materials and the noncombustible portion of refuse loaded into an incinerator. 
    Basement shall mean a portion of a building located partly underground, but having less than half its clear, floor-to-ceiling height below the grade plane as defined by the state basic building code. 
    Cellar shall mean a portion of a building located partly or wholly underground, and having half or more than half of the clear floor-to-ceiling height below the grade plane as defined by the state basic building code. 
    Central heating system shall mean a single system supplying heat to one (1) or more dwelling units or more than one (1) rooming unit. 
    Code enforcement officer shall mean the official charged with the administration and enforcement of this chapter, or his authorized representative. 
    Commercial activity shall mean any wholesale or retail sale of goods, commodities, insurance, or services or the activities which make possible such sale. 
    Commercial structure shall mean any structure which is wholly or partly used or intended to be used for the wholesale or retail sale of goods, commodities, insurance, or services or for the activities which make possible such sale. 
    Commercial unit shall mean any unit excluding those portions which are used as dwellings, dwelling units or habitable rooms, which is used or partly used or intended to be used for the wholesale or retail sale of goods, commodities, insurance, or services, or for the activities which make possible such sale by a single owner or operator, company or corporation. 
    Dwelling shall mean any enclosed space which is wholly or partly used or intended to be used for living or sleeping by human occupants, provided that temporary housing shall not be regarded as a dwelling. 
    Dwelling unit shall mean any room or group of rooms located within a dwelling and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Extermination shall mean the control and elimination of insects, rodents, or other pests by eliminating their harborages, by removing, or making inaccessible, materials that may serve as their food; by poisoning, spraying, fumigating, trapping, or by any other recognized and legal pest elimination methods approved by the health officer. 
    Family shall mean a person or group of related persons, plus guests and domestic servants thereof, or a group of not more than six (6) persons who need not be so related, who are living as a single housekeeping unit maintaining a common household. A roomer or boarder to whom rooms are let or board is furnished shall not be considered a member of a family. 
    Flush watercloset shall mean a toilet bowl flushed with water under pressure with a water sealed trap above the floor level. 
    Garbage shall mean the animal and vegetable waste resulting from handling, preparation, cooking, serving and nonconsumption of food. 
    Guest shall mean any person who shares a dwelling unit in a nonpermanent status for not more than thirty (30) days in a calendar year. 
    Habitable room shall mean a room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking, or eating purposes, excluding bathrooms, water closet compartments, laundries, furnace rooms, pantries, kitchenettes and utility rooms of less than fifty (50) square feet, foyers or communicating corridors, stairways, closets, storage spaces and workshops, hobby and recreation areas in unsealed or uninsulated parts of a structure below ground level or in attics or hobby and recreation areas for communal use in buildings containing several dwelling units. 
    Health officer shall mean the legally designated health authority of the city or his authorized representative. 
    Heated water shall mean water heated to a temperature of not less than one hundred twenty (120) degrees Fahrenheit at the outlet. 
    Hotel shall mean a building or portion of a building used as a place where sleeping accommodations are furnished for hire or other consideration, with or without board for sixteen (16) or more guests or employees of the management. The term "hotel" shall include all clubs, schools, dormitories or other buildings which have similar sleeping accommodations, but shall not include apartment houses, hospitals, penal institutions or buildings housing the insane. Members of the management's family shall not be considered as guests or employees. 
    Household shall mean a family of one (1) or more unrelated persons, including servants and not more than two (2) boarders, who share the same dwelling and use some or all of its cooking and eating facilities. 
    Infestation shall mean the presence of insects, rodents or other pests within or around a dwelling or other structure in numbers considered hazardous. 
    Kitchen or kitchenette shall mean any room containing any or all of the following equipment, or area of a room within three (3) feet of such equipment: sink or other device for dish washing, stove or other device for cooking, refrigerator or other device for cool storage of food. 
    Lavatory shall mean a bowl or basin for washing the face and hands, or a room equipped with such a basin. 
    Lead paint shall mean any pigmented, liquid substance applied to surfaces by brush, roller or spray, in which the total nonvolatile ingredient contains more than five-tenths (0.5) percent of lead, by weight, calculated as metallic lead. 
    Meaning of certain words. Wherever the words "dwelling," "dwelling unit," "rooming house," "rooming unit," "commercial structure," "commercial unit," "premises," and "structure" are used in this chapter, they shall be construed as though they were followed by the words "or any part thereof". 
    Motel shall be defined the same as hotel. 
    Multiple dwelling shall mean any dwelling containing more than three (3) dwelling units. 
    Occupant shall mean any person, over one (1) year of age, living, sleeping, cooking, or eating in, or actually having possession of, a dwelling unit or a rooming unit, except that in dwelling units a guest will not be considered an occupant. 
    Operator shall mean any person who has charge, care or control of a building, or part thereof, in which dwelling units or rooming units are let, or where commercial activity is conducted. 
    Owner shall mean any person, who, alone or jointly or severally with others: 
(a)  Shall have legal title to any commercial structure or commercial unit or dwelling or dwelling unit, with or without accompanying actual possession thereof; or 
(b)  Shall have charge, care or control of any commercial structure or commercial unit, dwelling, or dwelling unit as owner or agent of the owner, or as executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner. Any such person thus representing the actual owner shall be bound to comply with the provisions of this chapter and of rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto to the same extent as if he were the owner. 
    Permissible occupancy shall mean the maximum number of persons permitted as family or household to reside in a dwelling unit or rooming unit based on the required square footage per person in habitable rooms. 
    Person shall mean and include any individual, firm, corporation, association or partnership. 
    Plumbing shall mean and include all of the following supplied facilities and equipment: gas pipes, gas burning equipment, water pipes, garbage disposal units, waste pipes, water closets, sinks, installed dishwashers, lavatories, bathtubs, shower baths, installed clothes washing machines, catch basins, drains, vents, and other similar supplied fixtures, together with all connections to water, sewer, septic tank or gas lines. 
    Premises shall mean a plotted lot or part thereof, or unplotted lot or parcel of land, or plot of land, either occupied or unoccupied by any dwelling or nondwelling structure, and including any such building, accessory structure or other structure thereon. 
    Privacy shall mean the ability of a person or persons to carry out an activity commenced without observation, unwarranted interruption, or unwarranted interference, either by sight or sound, by unwanted persons. 
    Refuse shall mean all putrescible and nonputrescible solids (except body wastes) including garbage, rubbish, ashes and dead animals. 
    Rodent proofing shall mean a form of construction which will prevent the ingress or egress of rodents to or from a given space or building, or gaining access to food, water or harborage. It consists of the closing and keeping closed of every opening in foundations, basements, cellars, exterior and interior walls, ground or first floors, roofs, sidewalk gratings, sidewalk openings, and other places that may be reached and entered by rodents by climbing, burrowing or other methods, by the use of materials impervious to rodent gnawing and other methods approved by the appropriate authority. 
    Rooming house shall mean any dwelling or that part of any dwelling containing one (1) or more rooms in which living and sleeping accommodations are let, or intended to be let by the owner or operator, to five (5) to fifteen (15) guests who are not husband or wife, son or daughter, mother or father, or sister or brother of the owner; provided that hospitals, homes for the aged, and other institutions licensed by the state department of health under chapter 333 of the Connecticut General Statutes shall not be regarded as rooming houses. 
    Rooming unit shall mean any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit used or intended to be used for living and sleeping, but not for cooking or eating purposes, excluding rooms in convalescent and nursing homes. 
    Rubbish shall mean nonputrescible solid wastes (excluding ashes) consisting of both: 
(a)  Combustible wastes such as paper, cardboard, plastic containers, yard clippings, and wood; and 
(b)  Noncombustible wastes such as tin cans, glass and crockery. 
    Safety shall mean the condition of being free from danger and hazards which may cause accidents or disease. 
    Septic tank shall mean an underground receptacle to which sewage is drained and retained to effect disintegration of the organic matter by bacteria, and as defined in section 19-13-B20A of the state public health code, as revised. 
    Space heater shall mean a self-contained, automatically controlled, vented, fuel-burning appliance of either the circulating type or the radiant type. 
    Supplied shall mean paid for, furnished, provided by, or under the control of the owner or operator. 
    Temporary housing shall mean any trailer, mobile home, or any other structure used for human shelter which is designed to be transportable and is not attached to the ground, to another structure, or to any utility system on the same premises for more than thirty (30) consecutive days. 
    Ventilation shall mean the process of supplying or removing air by natural or mechanical means to or from any space. Such air may or may not have been conditioned. 
    Workmanlike. Whenever the words "workmanlike state of maintenance and repair" are used in this chapter, they shall mean that such maintenance and repair shall be made in a reasonably skillful manner. 
    Yard shall mean an open unoccupied space, on the same lot with a building extending along the entire length of a street, or rear, or interior lot line, or other unoccupied space on a lot with a building. 
(Ord. No. 310, §§ 2.01-2.51, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, §§ 2.01-2.51, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-5. - Liability of officials. 
    The director of inspection and compliance, code enforcement officer and his assistants shall be free from personal liability for acts done in good faith in the performance of official duties. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 23.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 23.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-6. - Lawsuits against officers, agents, employees, to be defended by corporation counsel. 
    Any suit brought against any officer, agent, or employee of the municipality, as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this Code, shall be defended by the legal representative of the municipality until the final determination of the proceedings therein. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 23.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 23.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-7. - Compliance with state building code required. 
    All new residential rentals or commercial construction or any reconstruction initiated after the effective date of this chapter shall be in compliance with the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.01, 4-12-07) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 8-8. - Conflicts between codes, ordinances or regulations. 
    In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with any existing code, ordinance, or regulation of this City of Shelton existing on the effective date of this chapter, the provision which established the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 23.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 23.01, 4-12-070 
Sec. 8-9. - Housing site development agency designated. 
    The community development office of the City of Shelton has been designated a housing site development agency as per Public Act 88-280, section 1, of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 569, 6-8-89) 
Sec. 8-10. - Identification of a landlord. 
(a)  Every nonresident property owner or their agents in charge of any rental property within the city limits shall be required to maintain their current residential address and telephone number(s) on file with the fire marshal of the City of Shelton. On and after thirty (30) days of the effective date of this section and upon request by the fire marshal; the property owner shall file with the fire marshal of the City of Shelton a statement containing such information together with five (5) copies thereof. The fire marshal shall provide one (1) copy to each of the following: building official, chief of police and to such other departments as the board of aldermen may by resolution direct from time to time. 
(b)  The property owner or agent shall maintain the residential address on file whether the rental property is occupied or vacant. 
(c)  The property owner or agent shall inform the fire marshal when his/her residential address changes not more than seven (7) days after the date that the address change occurred. The fire marshal shall notify the individuals designated in paragraph (a) above. 
(d)  If the nonresident owner or agent fails to file an address and telephone number(s) including cell phones with the city, the address to which the city mails property tax bills for the rental property shall be deemed to be the nonresident owner or agent's current address. 
(e)  Service of state or municipal orders relating to maintenance of such rental real property or compliance with state law and local codes concerning such real property directed to the nonresident owner or agent at the address on file, or deemed to be on file in accordance with the provisions of this section, shall be sufficient proof of service of notice of such orders in any subsequent criminal or civil action against the owner or agent for failure to comply with the orders. 
(f)  Any person who violates any provision of the section after being requested by the fire marshal for the requested information shall be subject to a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each day that the violation continues. The city may place a lien on the land records for any property owner in violation of this section which lien shall state the effective date that the lien commenced. 
(g)  The fire marshal and assistant fire marshals are designated to enforce this section and the fire marshal shall issue citations for violations hereof. 
(h)  Definitions: 
    Address means a location as described by the full street number, if any, street name, the city or town and the state. A post office box shall not be considered an address. 
    Agent in charge means one who manages real estate, including, but not limited to, the collection of rents and supervision of property. 
    Dwelling unit means any house, or building, or portion thereof (which includes single, family, multifamily apartment building, apartment, etc.), which is rented, leased or hired out to be occupied, or is arranged or designed to be occupied, as the home or residence of one (1) or more persons, living independently of each other, and doing their cooking upon the premises, and having a common right in the halls, stairways or yards. 
    Nonresident shall mean a property owner who does not reside at the property. 
(Ord. No. 827, 6-12-07; Ord. No. 857, 2-10-11) 
Secs. 8-11-8-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS OF NONCOMMERCIAL STRUCTURES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-21. - Housing code certificate of occupancy required. 
    A housing code certificate of occupancy shall be issued after approval of a rented dwelling or dwelling unit by the code enforcement officer. It shall be the responsibility of each owner to notify the code enforcement officer of all vacancies in rented dwellings or dwelling units and as vacancies occur. The code enforcement officer shall inspect a rented dwelling or dwelling unit no later than two (2) normal working days after receiving an application for a housing code certificate of occupancy. No rented dwelling or dwelling unit may be let unless and until it has been inspected and approved and the housing code certificate of occupancy has been issued by the code enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-22. - Dwellings and premises to be clean, sanitary and fit before occupancy. 
    No person shall let to another person any vacant dwelling or dwelling unit unless it and the premises are clean, sanitary, fit for human occupancy, and comply with all applicable legal requirements of the state and the city. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-23. - Owners to keep shared or public areas sanitary. 
    Every owner of a dwelling containing two (2) or more dwelling units shall maintain in a clean and sanitary condition the shared or public areas of the dwelling and premises thereof. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-24. - Occupant to maintain premises in sanitary condition. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall maintain in a clean and sanitary condition that part or those parts of the dwelling, dwelling unit and premises thereof that he occupies and controls. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.05, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-25. - Safe and sanitary disposal of rubbish. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all his rubbish in a clean, sanitary and safe manner. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.06, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.06, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-26. - Safe and sanitary storage of garbage and organic waste. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall store and dispose of all his refuse and garbage and any other organic waste which might provide harborage or food for rodents or insects, in a clean, sanitary and safe manner, and, if a container is used for storage pending collection, it shall always conform to city refuse collection ordinance requirements. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.07, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.07, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-27. - Owner to provide screens, storm doors, storm windows; occupant to maintain. 
    The owner of the dwelling or dwelling unit shall provide and hang all screens and double or storm doors and storm windows or thermopane equivalent. Maintenance or replacement of screens, storm doors and windows, once installed, become the responsibility of the occupant. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.08, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 367, 2-13-79; Ord. No. 806, § 3.08, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-28. - Extermination of insects and rodents. 
(a)  Responsibilities of occupants. Every occupant of a dwelling containing a single dwelling unit shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents, or other pests therein or on the premises; and every occupant of a dwelling unit, in a dwelling containing more than one (1) dwelling unit, shall be responsible for such extermination whenever his dwelling is the only one infested. 
(b)  Responsibilities of owners. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, whenever infestation is caused by failure of the owner to maintain a dwelling in a rodent proof or reasonable insect proof condition, extermination shall be the responsibility of the owner. Whenever, infestation exists in two (2) units or more of the dwelling containing two (2) or more dwelling units, extermination thereof shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.09, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.09, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-29. - Occupant to use care in the use and operation of plumbing fixtures. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling unit or structure shall keep all plumbing fixtures and facilities therein in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be responsible for the exercise of reasonable care in the proper use and operation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.10, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.10, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-30. - Rubbish accumulation. 
    Every owner of a dwelling containing two (2) units or more dwelling units, and every occupant of a dwelling containing a single dwelling unit shall be responsible for preventing an accumulation on the premises of boxes, lumber, scrap metal or other materials which may provide insect or rodent harborage or food. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 3.11, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 3.11, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-31-8-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ROOMING HOUSES, HOTELS AND MOTELS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prohibit and regulate the construction of boarding houses, hotels, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(A)(viii). 

Sec. 8-41. - Compliance with article required. 
    No person shall operate a rooming house, hotel or motel, or shall occupy, or let to another for occupancy, and rooming house, hotel or motel unit except in compliance with the provisions of this chapter and zoning regulations of the City of Shelton. No owner or other person shall occupy, or let to another person, any vacant unit unless it is clean, sanitary and fit for human occupancy, and in compliance with all applicable requirements of the City of Shelton. 
(Ord. No. 310, Ch. IX, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, Ch. IX, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-42. - Water closets, lavatory basins, bathtubs and showers. 
    At least one (1) flush water closet, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower, properly connected to a water and sewer system or septic tank system, approved by the code enforcement officer and in good working condition, shall be supplied for each six (6) persons, or fraction thereof, residing within a rooming house, hotel or motel, including members of the operator's family, wherever they share the use of said facilities, provided: 
(1)  In a rooming house, hotel or motel unit where rooms are let only to males, flush urinals may be substituted for not more than one-half (1/2) the required number of water closets. 
(2)  All such facilities shall be so located within the premises as to be reasonably accessible from a common hall or passageway to all persons sharing such facilities. 
(3)  Each lavatory basin and bathtub or shower shall be supplied with adequate hot water under pressure. 
(4)  No such facilities shall be located in a basement or cellar except by written approval of the code enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-43. - Cooking prohibited. 
    Cooking in a rooming house, hotel or motel unit shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-44. - Communal cooking, dining facilities prohibited; exception. 
    Communal cooking and dining facilities in a rooming house, hotel or motel shall be prohibited, except as approved by the Valley Health Department. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-45. - Units to have operating locks. 
    Rooming unit, hotel or motel unit doors shall have operating locks to insure privacy. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.05, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-46. - Bed linen and towels. 
    The operator of every rooming house, hotel or motel shall change supplied bed linen and towels therein at least once a week, and prior to the letting of any room to any occupant, except where an arrangement exists between the owner and occupant in writing. The operator shall be responsible for the maintenance of all supplied bedding in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.06, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.06, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-47. - Required space in rooming house sleeping rooms. 
    Every room occupied for sleeping purposes in a rooming house by one (1) person shall contain at least eighty (80) square feet of floor space, and every room occupied for sleeping by more than one (1) person shall contain at least forty (40) square feet of floor space for each additional occupant thereof, provided no more than three (3) occupants shall occupy the same room. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.07, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.07, 4-12-07) 
State Law reference- Overcrowding in tenement and lodginghouses, G.S. § 47a-54a. 
Sec. 8-48. - Means of egress required. 
    Every rooming house, hotel or motel shall have two (2) or more safe, unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level, as required by the laws of this city and this state. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.08, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.08, 4-12-07) 
State Law reference- Required stairways and fire escapes, G.S. § 19-386. 
Sec. 8-49. - Unit windows to have drapes, etc. 
    Every window of every rooming house, hotel or motel unit shall be supplied with shades, draw drapes, or other devices or material which, when properly used, will afford privacy to the occupant of the rooming unit. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.09, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.09, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-50. - Unit arrangement. 
    Access to or egress from each rooming unit shall be provided without passing through any other rooming unit. A bathroom or water closet compartment shall not be used as the passageway to any hall, basement, or cellar, or to the exterior of a dwelling unit. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.10, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.10, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-51. - Maintenance standards for hotel, motel operators. 
(a)  Each hotel or motel operator shall observe and comply with the following standards in the maintenance of the premises operated by him: 
(1)  Size of sleeping rooms. The sleeping room occupied by each occupant shall contain not less than one hundred (100) square feet in single-occupancy rooms and not less than seventy-five (75) square feet per person for multiple-occupancy rooms. 
(2)  Toilet facilities. The toilet facilities for each room shall be adequate and there shall be a lavatory and bath or shower with running hot and cold water and a toilet with cold running water at all times and at least one (1) such facility for each six (6) person or fraction thereof using each facility. The shower shall have a shower curtain in good repair or the shower area should be otherwise enclosed. A tub mat, safety strips, or a built-in slip-resistant tub shall be supplied. 
(3)  Window space. Each room used for sleeping purposes shall contain at least one (1) outside window of not less than ten (10) percent of floor area which shall be so constructed that at least forty-five (45) percent opens readily except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by appropriate authority. 
(4)  Exterior and interior physical condition. Furniture, walls, ceilings, lighting, drapes, Venetian blinds, carpets, floors, elevators, windows, and wall decorations shall be clean and neat and in good physical repair. Stairways, walkways, and lobbies shall be clean and uncluttered. Refuse and rubbish shall not be allowed to accumulate in or on any portion of the premises used as a hotel or motel but shall be kept in approved receptacles and containers. 
(5)  Guest room supplies. Drinking glasses, where supplied, should be sanitized in accordance with state and local ordinances. A waste basket will be provided in every room. Soap and toilet tissues are to be supplied in sufficient quantity. A fresh supply of soap is to be provided with each new occupant. Towels and wash cloths that have been used shall be replaced daily. Bed linens, pillows, mattresses, mattress pads, box springs, springs, and frames shall be clean, in good repair and free of stains and foreign matter. Clean bed linens shall be supplied at least once a week and prior to the letting of any room to any occupant. 
(6)  Mechanical room and storage area. Ceilings, walls, pipes, pumps, heating and air conditioning equipment should all be neat and clean, well painted and in good repair. Floors must be clean, uncluttered and free of safety hazards. 
(7)  Food and drink vending machines. Where supplied to hotel or motel guests, vending machines shall be kept in a clean and sanitary manner. All refrigerated drinking fountains shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary manner. All ice machines shall be supplied with scoops and/or tong which shall not be stored in ice chest of machine. 
(8)  Restaurants. All Restaurant facilities are to comply with the State of Connecticut Public Health Code and city ordinances. Restaurant facilities must have a separate identity from hotel or motel living quarters and are to be licenses by the Valley Health Department. 
(9)  Swimming pools. All swimming pool shall comply with the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code, the State of Connecticut Public Health Code, all City of Shelton ordinances and zoning regulations. 
(10)  Rodent and vermin infestation, etc. The entire premises constituting the hotel or motel shall be kept free of rodent and vermin infestation. 
(11)  Operating locks. All hotel or motel rooms shall have operating locks to insure privacy. 
(b)  In addition to the specific terms of this section, the housing code enforcement officer shall have the power to order the rectification of any condition or situation in any hotel or motel licenses hereunder which, in his opinion, is detrimental or dangerous to life and public safety. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.11, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.11, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-52. - Permit-Required; display; transferability; change of ownership; expiration. 
    No person shall operate a rooming house, hotel or motel unless he holds a valid rooming house, hotels, motel permit issued by the code enforcement officer in the name of the operator and for the specific premises specified therein. The operator shall apply to the code enforcement officer upon compliance by the operator with the applicable provisions of this chapter and with any rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. This permit shall be displayed in a conspicuous place within the rooming house, hotel or motel at all times. No such permit shall be transferable. Every person holding such permit shall give notice in writing to the code enforcement officer within twenty-four (24) hours after having sold, transferred, given away, or otherwise disposed of ownership of, interest in, or control of any rooming house, hotel or motel. Such notices shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such rooming house, hotel or motel. Every rooming house, hotel or motel permit shall expire at the end of the year following its date of issuance, unless sooner suspended or revoked as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-53. - License-Requirements. 
    No person shall subsequent to the effective date of this chapter, operate a rooming house, hotel or motel, as herein defined, within the City of Shelton unless a rooming house or hotel or motel license shall be issued to him as herein provided. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the housing code enforcement officer upon such forms as may be prescribed by him. Such application, whether original or for renewal of a license already issued, shall contain in addition to such other information as may be required by the housing code enforcement officer, the applicant's name, address, the address at which he proposed to operate a rooming house, hotel or motel, the number of rooms, roomers, and beds to be for hire, the number of beds and roomers in each room, and the name of the individuals who will be charged with the control, management and maintenance of said rooming house, motel or hotel. Application for the renewal of a license already issued shall be made to the housing code enforcement officer not later than one (1) month prior to the date of the expiration of the existing license. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.12, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.12, 4-12-07) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 8-54. - Same-Application; expiration. 
    Each original application for the licensing of a rooming house, hotel or motel, must be accompanied by a certificate of zoning compliance, issued by the zoning officer, certifying that the proposed use of the premises is a permitted use under the zoning regulations of the City of Shelton. Upon acceptance of an application for the licensing of a rooming house, hotel or motel, original or renewal, the code enforcement officer shall cause the premises to be inspected within seven (7) days, with the assistance, as he may require, of the police, fire, building and valley health departments. Upon certification of these departments, as may be required, that the premises comply with the applicable rules, regulations, ordinances and statutes within the jurisdiction of these departments and with the housing code of the City of Shelton, the code enforcement officer shall, upon payment of the prescribed free, issue the operating license to the applicant within fifteen (15) days after all certifications and/or approvals are received. If the premises or the applicant shall fail to meet or pass all the foregoing requirements, the application shall be denied. Each license issued hereunder shall expire one (1) year from the issued date recorded thereon, unless sooner revoked in the manner herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.13, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.13, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-55. - Same-Display. 
    Each rooming house, hotel and motel operator shall be responsible for plainly displaying the license granted to him hereunder in a prominent place within said premises. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.13, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.13a), 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-56. - Suitability of licensees. 
    The chief of police may require such information as will disclose whether the applicant has been convicted of keeping a house of ill-fame or assignation, or a house in which lewd, dissolute or drunken person resort or which has been used for the purpose of gaming. If any applicant shall have been convicted of any of the aforesaid offenses or has such criminal record that the chief of police reasonably believes that he is not a suitable person to be licensed hereunder, he may in his discretion, so advices the housing code enforcement officer not to issue a license to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.14, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.14, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-57. - Suspension of license. 
    The code enforcement officer, chief of police, fire marshal, building official and Valley Health Department Director are hereby authorized and shall have the power to enter, inspect and examine, or cause to be entered, inspected and examined, any portion of all rooming houses, hotels and motels licensed hereunder. Whenever, upon inspection at any of these premises, the code enforcement officer finds, or any of the other aforementioned authorities submits to the code enforcement officer a report of their findings that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provisions of this chapter, or of any applicable rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto, the code enforcement officer shall give notice in writing to the operator of such facilities that unless such conditions are corrected within a reasonable time, the operator's license will be suspended. At the end of such period of time the code enforcement officer shall reinspect such facilities, under the conditions of his first entry and inspection as set forth in this subsection above; and, if he determines that such conditions have not been corrected, he shall issue an order suspending the operator's license. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.15, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.15, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-58. - Appeal on suspension of license. 
    Any person whose license to operate a rooming house, hotel or motel has been suspended by order of the code enforcement officer may petition for and shall be granted a hearing on the matter in the manner prescribed by section 8-186 et seq., on hearings. If no such petition is forthcoming within five (5) working days following the day on which the license was suspended, said license shall be deemed revoked, except that at any time within five (5) working days following such suspension any person whose license has been suspended shall have the opportunity to demonstrate to the code enforcement officer that his rooming house, hotel or motel has been put in compliance with this chapter and with all regulations pursuant thereto. Where such compliance is demonstrated to the satisfaction of the code enforcement officer, the suspension of the rooming house, hotel or motel license shall be terminated. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 9.16, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 9.16, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-59-8-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STANDARDS FOR NONCOMMERCIAL STRUCTURES 

Sec. 8-66. - Compliance with article required. 
    No person shall let to another for occupancy, any dwelling or dwelling unit for the purposes of living, sleeping, cooking, or eating therein, which does not comply with the following requirements. 
(Ord. No. 310, Ch. IV, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, Ch. IV, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-67. - Food preparation and cooking facilities. 
    Every dwelling unit shall have a room or portion of a room in which food may be prepared and/or cooked, and which shall be equipped with the following: 
(1)  Kitchen sink. A kitchen sink in good working condition apart from the lavatory sink required in section 8-69, and properly connected to a water supply system which is approved by the appropriate authority, and which provides an adequate amount of heated and unheated running water under pressure, and which is connected to a sewer system or septic tank system which is approved by the appropriate authority. 
(2)  Cabinets and/or shelves. Cabinets and/or shelves for the storage of eating and drinking and cooking equipment and utensils, and of food that does not, under ordinary maximum summer conditions, require refrigeration for safe keeping; said cabinets and/or shelves shall be adequate for the permissible occupancy of the dwelling unit. 
(3)  Stove and refrigerator. A stove or similar device for cooking food, and a refrigerator, or similar device, for the safe storage of food at temperatures less than forty-five (45) degrees Fahrenheit, but more than thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit, under ordinary maximum summer conditions, which are properly installed with all necessary connections for safe, sanitary and efficient operation, provided that such stove, refrigerator, and/or similar devices, need not be installed when a dwelling unit is not occupied and when the occupant is expected to provide same on occupancy, that sufficient space for the safe and efficient installation and operation of said stove, refrigerator and/or similar devices, is provided. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-68. - Flush water closet required. 
    Within every dwelling unit there shall be a nonhabitable room, affording privacy to a person within said room, which is equipped with a flush water closet in good working condition. Said flush water closet shall be connected to a water system that at all times provides an adequate amount of running water under pressure so as to cause the flush water closet to be operated properly, and shall be connected to a sewer system or septic tank which is approved by the appropriate authority. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-69. - Lavatory required. 
    Within every dwelling unit there shall be a room, affording privacy to a person, which is equipped with a lavatory. Said lavatory shall be in the same room as the flush water closet. The lavatory shall be in good working condition and properly connected to a water supply system which is approved by the appropriate authority, and which provides an adequate amount of heated and unheated, running water under pressure, and to a sewer system or septic tank system which is approved by the appropriate authority. Said requirement may be waived by the building official and the code enforcement officer when they agree that said installation would be impossible. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-70. - Bathtub or shower required. 
    Within every dwelling unit there shall be a nonhabitable room, which affords privacy to a person within said room, and which is equipped with a bathtub or shower bath in good working condition. Said bathtub or shower bath may be in the same room as the flush water closet, or in another room, and shall be properly connected to a water supply system which is approved by appropriate authority and which provides an adequate amount of heated and unheated, running water under pressure, and to a sewer system or septic tank which is approved by the appropriate authority. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-71. - Proximity of habitable rooms, bathrooms or water closets to commercial uses. 
    No habitable room, bathroom or water closet compartment which is accessory to a dwelling unit shall open directly into, or shall be used in conjunction with a food store, public eating room, food preparation room, barber or beauty shop, doctor's or dentist's examination or treatment room or office, or any similar room used for public purposes, or other areas as outlined in the state public health code. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.05, 4-12-07 
Sec. 8-72. - Roof requirements. 
    The roof shall be structurally sound, tight, and have no defects which might admit rain, and roof drainage shall be adequate to prevent rain water from causing dampness in the walls or interior portion of the building. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.06, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.06, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-73. - Floor requirements. 
    Every floor shall be reasonably weather tight, water tight, and damp free, and shall be kept structurally sound and in good repair. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.07, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.07, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-74. - Windows, exterior doors, hatchway requirements. 
    Every window, exterior door and basement hatchway or similar devices, shall be rodent proof and reasonably watertight, and shall be kept in sound working condition and good repair, and shall be quipped with operating locks. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.08, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.08, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-75. - Window sashes to have glass panes or approved substitute. 
    Every window sash shall be supplied with glass window panes or an approved substitute. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.09, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.09, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-76. - Rodentproofing required for ground level windows, openings. 
    Every window located at or near ground level, or intended to be used for ventilation, and every other opening located at or near ground level which might provide entry for rodents, shall be supplied with adequate gauge screening or such other devices as will effectively prevent their entrance. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 4.10, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 4.10, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-77. - Means of egress from dwelling unit required. 
    Every dwelling until shall have two (2) or more approved means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level, as required by the laws of the State of Connecticut and the City of Shelton. 
(Ord. No. 310, §§ 4.11, 8.08, 5-8-78 ; Ord. No. 806, §§ 4.11, 8.08, 4-12-07) 
State Law reference- Required stairways and fire escapes, G.S. § 19-386. 
Sec. 8-78. - Minimum window or skylight areas required. 
    Every habitable room shall have at least one (1) window or skylight facing directly outdoors. The minimum total window area, measured betweens tops, for every habitable room shall be not less than ten (10) percent of the floor area of such room. Wherever walls, or other portions of structures, face a window of any such room, and such light-obstructing structures are located less than three (3) feet from the window and extend to a level above that of the ceiling of the room, such window shall not be deemed to face directly to the outdoors and shall not be included as contributing to the required minimum total window area. Whenever the only window in a room is a skylight type window in the top of such room, the total window area of such skylight shall equal at least ten (10) percent of the total floor area of such room. Each window shall be not less than three (3) square feet in area. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 5.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 5.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-79. - Operable window or skylight areas required. 
    Every habitable room shall have at least one (1) window or skylight which can be easily opened, or such other device as will adequately ventilate the room. The total of openable window area in every habitable room shall be equal to at least forty-five (45) percent of the minimum window area size, or minimum skylight type window size, as required in section 8-78 of this chapter, except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the housing code enforcement officer or building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 5.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 5.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-80. - Lighting and ventilation requirements for kitchenette, bathroom and water closet compartments. 
    Every kitchenette, bathroom and water closet compartment shall comply with the light and ventilation requirements for habitable rooms contained in sections 8-78 and 8-79, except that no window or skylight shall bee required in such rooms equipped with a ventilation system which his in compliance with the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 5.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 5.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-81. - Electrical service, outlets and fixtures. 
    Every dwelling unit, and all public and common areas, shall be supplied with electric service, outlets, and fixtures which shall be properly installed, shall be maintained in good and safe working condition, and shall be connected to the source of electric power in a manner prescribed by the ordinances, rules and regulations of the City of Shelton. The minimum capacity of such services, and the number of outlets and fixtures, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Every habitable room shall have an electric service and outlets and/or fixtures capable of providing at least three (3) watts per square foot of floor area. 
(2)  Every habitable room and nonhabitable room used for food preparation shall have at least one (1) floor or wall-type duplex electric convenience outlet for each sixty (60) square feet, or fraction thereof, of floor area. 
(3)  Every water closet compartment, bathroom, kitchen or kitchenette, laundry room, furnace room and public hall shall contain at least one (1) supplied ceiling or wall type of electric light fixture. 
(4)  Every water closet compartment, bathroom, kitchen or kitchenette, laundry room and furnace room shall contain at least one (1) floor or wall-type duplex electric convenience outlet, except that kitchens or kitchenettes shall have at least two (2) duplex electric convenience outlets. 
(5)  Convenient switches for turning on lights shall be located in accordance with the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code. 
(6)  Every dwelling unit shall be supplied with a maximum of sixty (60) amperes of electric service. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 5.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 5.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-82. - Lighting in public halls and stairways in multiple dwellings. 
    Every public hall and stairway in every multiple dwelling shall be adequately lighted by natural or artificial light at all times so as to provide at least six (6) footcandles of light at the tread or floor level. Every public hall and stairway in structures containing not more than three (3) dwelling units, may be supplied with conveniently located light switches, controlling an adequate system which may be turned on when needed, instead of fulltime lighting. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 5.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 5.05, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-83. - Heating facilities required; minimum temperature capability required. 
    Every dwelling or dwelling unit shall be supplied with heating facilities which are properly installed, are maintained in safe and good working conditions, and are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms, kitchen or kitchenette, bathrooms and water closet compartments located therein to a temperature of not less than sixty-eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit at five (5) feet above the floor at all times, and shall be installed and operated in the manner required by the statutes, ordinances and regulations of the State of Connecticut and the City of Shelton. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 6.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 6.01, 4-12-07) 
State Law reference- Required heating, G.S. § 19a-109. 
Sec. 8-84. - Minimum floor space required for occupancy. 
    Every dwelling unit shall contain at least one hundred fifty (150) square feet of floor space for the first occupant thereof, and at least one hundred ten (110) square feet of floor space for additional occupant thereof, the floor space to be calculated on the basis of total habitable room space. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 8.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 8.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-85. - Minimum floor space required in sleeping rooms. 
    In every dwelling unit of two (2) or more rooms, every room occupied for sleeping purposes shall contain at least seventy (70) square feet of floor space for the first occupant, and at least fifty (50) square feet of floor space for each additional occupant thereof, and shall be no less than seven (7) feet in width. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 8.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 8.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-86. - Room arrangements. 
    No dwelling or dwelling unit containing two (2) or more sleeping rooms, shall have such room arrangement that access to a bathroom or water closet compartment, intended for use by occupants of more than one (1) sleeping room, can be had only going through another sleeping room. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 8.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 8.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-87. - Ceiling height. 
    At least seventy-five (75) percent of the floor area of every habitable room shall have a ceiling height of no less than seven (7) feet four (4) inches and the floor area of that part of any room where the ceiling height is less than five (5) feet, shall not be considered as part of the floor area of the room for the purpose of determining the maximum permissible occupancy thereof. At least fifty (50) percent of the floor area in attic rooms shall have a ceiling height of seven (7) feet.
