(Ord. No. 310, § 8.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 8.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-88. - Use of space below grade as habitable room. 
    No space, located totally or partially below grade, shall be used as a habitable room or dwelling unit, unless: 
(1)  The floor, and those portions of the walls below grade, are of waterproof and dampproof construction. 
(2)  The minimum window area, required in section 8-78, is located entirely above grade of the ground adjoining such window area or, if windows are located below grade, that there be constructed a properly drained window well whose ground area shall be equal to, or greater than, the area of the window opening; the bottom of the window shall be below the top of the impervious masonry under this window; the minimum horizontal projections of the bottom of the window well shall be equal to, or greater than, the vertical dimension of this window opening, and no part of the window well, opposite this window, shall protrude above a line projected at a forty-five-degree angle from the bottom of the window opening at right angles to the outer wall. 
(3)  The total openable window area in each room is equal to at least the minimum, as required under section 8-79 of this chapter, except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the appropriate authority. 
(4)  There are no pipes, or other obstructions less than six (6) feet eight (8) inches above the floor level which interfere with the normal use of the room or area. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 8.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 8.05, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-89. - Storage space. 
(a)  Every dwelling unit shall have at least four (4) square feet of floor to ceiling height closet space for the personal effects of each permissible occupant; if it is lacking, in whole or in part, an amount of space equal in square footage to the deficiency shall be subtracted from the area of habitable room space used in determining permissible occupancy. 
(b)  Each dwelling shall have a suitable facility for the safe storage of medicines, toxic materials, and household poisons, such as ammonia, paint, etc., to ensure safety for children in a residential environment. 
(Ord. No. 310, §§ 8.06, 8.07, 5-8-78 ; Ord. No. 806, §§ 8.06, 8.07, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-90. - Exterior property areas to be clean, sanitary. 
    All exterior property areas shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, free from any accumulation of garbage, rubbish and other debris. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-91. - Premises to be properly graded. 
    All premises shall be graded and maintained as to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon, or within any building or structure located thereon. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-92. - Exterior wood surfaces to be painted. 
    Every foundation, floor, wall, ceiling and roof shall be weathertight, watertight, and rodent proof and shall be kept in good repair. All exterior wood surfaces shall be protected from the elements and decay by paint or other protective covering or treatment. Toxic paint and materials will not be used on such exterior surfaces as are readily accessible to children. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-93. - Lead paint. 
(a)  Lead paint or potentially hazardous material on the interior surfaces of any dwelling unit, rooming unit, rooming house or on any fixtures or other objects used, installed or located in or upon any exposed surface in any such facility subject to letting or occupancy by children, is prohibited. Such interior surfaces shall include, but not be limited to, window sills, window frames, doors, door frames, walls, ceilings, stair rails and spindles, and all other appurtenances of the interior portion of the dwelling premises. 
(b)  In each instance where conditions disclose loose, flaking, chipping or falling paint, and there is reason to believe that the presence of lead paint or other toxic material exists as a potential hazard, the enforcing officer shall take samples for analysis to the Valley Health Department. Upon determination by Valley Health Department that lead paint is present, the code enforcement officer shall notify the landlord to take necessary procedures to rectify this problem. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, §§ 7.03.01, 7.03.02, 4-12-07) 
State Law reference- Restrictions on sale and use of paint, G.S. §§ 19-65a-19-65f. 
Sec. 8-94. - Exterior walls. 
    Every exterior wall shall be free of holes, breaks, loose or rotting boards or timbers, and any other conditions which might admit rain or dampness to the interior portions of the walls, or to the occupied spaces of the building. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-95. - Safety requirements for stairs, porches, railings and other exit facilities. 
    Stairs, porches, railings and other exit facilities shall be adequate for safety as provided by the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code, and shall comply with the following subsections: 
(1)  Every flight of stairs which is more than two (2) risers high shall have handrails which shall be located as required by the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code; 
(2)  Eery porch which is located more than three (3) feet higher than the adjacent area shall have handrails and balustrades or other approved protection so located and of such design as required by the building code; 
(3)  Every handrail and balustrade shall be firmly fastened and shall be maintained in good condition. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.05, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-96. - Structural parts of dwellings to be safe; capable of supporting normal loads. 
    Every foundation, roof, floor, exterior and interior wall, ceiling, inside and outside stair, every porch, and every appurtenance thereto, shall be safe to use and capable of supporting the loads that normal use may cause to be placed thereon, and be kept in sound condition and good repair. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.06, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.06, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-97. - Water closet compartment; bathroom floor surface. 
    Every water closet compartment, bathroom and kitchen floor surface shall be constructed and maintained so as to be reasonably impervious to water, and so permitting such floor to be easily kept in clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.07, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.07, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-98. - Supplied facilities; safe and effective. 
    Every plumbing fixture and pipe, every chimney flue and smoke pipe, and every other facility, piece of equipment, or utility which is present in a dwelling unit, or which is required under this chapter, shall be constructed and installed in conformance with the applicable local or state codes, at the time of construction or alteration, and shall be maintained in satisfactory working conditions. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.08, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.08, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-99. - Plumbing fixtures. 
    Every plumbing fixture, and water and waste pipe, shall be properly installed and maintained in good sanitary working condition. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.09, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.09, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-100. - Removal, discontinuance, of service facilities or utilities. 
    No owner, operator, or occupant shall cause any service, facility, equipment, or utility which is required under this chapter to be removed from, or shut off from, or discontinued from any occupied unit let or occupied by him except for such temporary interruption as may be necessary while actual repairs or alterations are in process, or during temporary emergencies when discontinuance of service is approved by the appropriate authority. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.10, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.10, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-101. - Fire protection. 
    All construction and materials, ways and means of egress, and all installation and use of equipment shall conform to applicable state and local laws dealing with fire and protection. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.11, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.11, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-102. - Application, maintenance of interior paint. 
    The responsibility for the application and maintenance of interior paint may be transferred by agreement between landlord and tenant, to the tenant. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 7.12, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 7.12, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-103-8-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INSPECTION OF DWELLINGS, DWELLING UNITS AND PREMISES 

Sec. 8-111. - Authorization to inspect; right of entry; purpose; policy re notice. 
(a)  All dwellings or dwelling units which are let shall be inspected when vacant in accordance with section 8-21, or in response to a complaint that an alleged violation of the provisions of this chapter may exist, or when the code enforcement officer has valid reason to believe that a violation of this chapter has been or is being committed. 
(b)  The code enforcement officer is hereby authorized and directed to make inspections, as authorized by this chapter, by and with the consent of the owner, occupant or person in charge, to determine the condition of the dwellings, dwelling units and premises within this city for the purposes of determining compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  For the purpose of making such inspections the code enforcement officer, with consent of the owner, occupant or person in charge, is hereby authorized to enter, examine and survey all dwellings, dwelling units and premises between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., or such other time mutually satisfactory to and agreed upon by the code of enforcement officer and the owner or occupant of a dwelling, dwelling unit, or the person in charge thereof. 
(d)  Such inspection, examination or survey shall be made so as to cause the least amount of inconvenience to said owner or occupant, consistent with an efficient performance of the duties of the code enforcement officer. The code enforcement officer shall make every effort to inspect a dwelling or dwelling unit no more than seven (7) working days after receipt of a complaint. 
(e)  To further ensure that the police of this chapter, which is to achieve compliance through cooperation of owners and occupants, be successfully maintained, it shall be the practice of the code enforcement officer, whenever practicable, to provide reasonable advance notice to owners and/or occupants of inspection. 
(Ord. No. 310, §§ 10.01, 10.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, §§ 10.01, 10.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-112. - Owner or occupant to grant right of entry; search warrant to be obtained upon denial; emergency right of entry; penalty. 
(a)  The owner or occupant of each dwelling, dwelling unit or premises, or the person in charge thereof, upon presentation by the code enforcement officer of proper identification, may give the code enforcement officer entry to the dwelling, dwelling unit, or premises, and free access to every part thereof, provided that no inspection shall be conducted except during the hours designated above, or at such time as is mutually satisfactory to and agreed upon by the code enforcement officer and the owner, agent or occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit. 
(b)  Whenever an owner, occupant or person in charge of a dwelling, dwelling unit, or premises shall deny the code enforcement officer right of entry for the purpose of inspection, examination or survey, the code enforcement officer shall not so enter until he presents a duly issued court order describing the dwelling, dwelling unit or premises, to the owner, occupant or person in charge thereof. 
(c)  Any owner, occupant, or person in charge of a dwelling, dwelling unit, or premises refusing to permit, or impeding entry of and free access to any part of any dwelling, dwelling unit or premises for the purposes of inspection, examination, or survey under the provisions of this subsection and section 8-111 above, shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 10.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 10.03, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-113-8-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS OF COMMERCIAL STRUCTURES 

Sec. 8-121. - Housing code certificate of occupancy required. 
    A housing code certificate of occupancy shall be issued after an inspection has been made and the premises approved by the code enforcement officer. It shall be the responsibility of the owner to notify the code enforcement officer of all vacancies in commercial structures or commercial units. No commercial structure or commercial unit may be let until it passed inspection and a certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 11.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 11.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-122. - Units must be clean, sanitary, fit for commercial activity. 
    No owner or other person shall occupy, or let to another person, any vacant commercial structure or unit unless it and the premises are clean, sanitary, fit for commercial activity, and comply with all applicable legal requirements of the State of Connecticut and the City of Shelton. Said restriction is lifted when the occupant or rentee has promised, in writing, to bring the property up to these requirements. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 11.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 11.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-123. - Owner to maintain shared, public areas. 
    Every owner of a commercial structure containing two (2) or more commercial units shall maintain in a clean and sanitary condition the shared or public areas of the structure and premises thereof. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 11.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 11.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-124. - Occupant to maintain occupied area in clean and sanitary condition. 
    Every occupant of a commercial structure or commercial unit shall maintain in a clean and sanitary condition that part or those parts of the commercial structure, commercial unit, and premises thereof, that he controls and occupies. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 11.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 11.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-125. - Occupant to dispose of rubbish. 
    Every occupant of a commercial structure, or commercial unit shall dispose of all his rubbish in a clean, sanitary and safe manner. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 11.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 11.05, 4-12-07) 
Cross reference- Garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 8-126. - Occupant to dispose of garbage and organic waste. 
    Every occupant of a commercial structure or commercial unit shall dispose of all has garbage and any other organic waste which might provide food for rodents in a clean, sanitary and safe manner, and if a container is used for storage pending collection, it shall be rodent proof, insect proof and watertight. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 11.06, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 11.06, 4-12-07) 
Cross reference- Garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 8-127. - Containers for rubbish and garbage required. 
    Every owner of a commercial structure containing three (3) or more units shall supply an area with facilities or containers for the sanitary and safe storage and/or disposal of rubbish and garbage. In the case of single or two-unit commercial structures it shall be the responsibility of the occupant to furnish such facilities or containers, if not supplied by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 11.07, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 11.07, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-128. - Extermination of insects and rodents. 
(a)  Responsibilities of occupants. Every occupant of a commercial structure containing a single unit shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents, or other pests therein or on the premises; and every occupant of a commercial unit, in a commercial structure containing more than one (1) commercial unit, shall be responsible for such extermination whenever his commercial unit is the only one infested. 
(b)  Responsibilities of owners. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this subsection, whenever infestation is caused by failure of the owner to maintain a dwelling in a rodent proof or reasonably insect proof condition, extermination shall be the responsibility of the owner. Whenever infestation exists in two (2) or more of the units in any commercial structure, or in the shared or public parts of any commercial structure containing two (2) or more units, extermination thereof shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 11:08, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 11.08, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-129. - Occupant responsibility for maintenance, care of plumbing fixtures. 
    Every occupant of a commercial unit shall keep all plumbing fixtures in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be responsible for the exercise of reasonable care in the proper use and operation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 11.09, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 11.09, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-130-8-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - STANDARDS FOR COMMERCIAL STRUCTURES 

Sec. 8-136. - Compliance with article required. 
    No person shall occupy as owner, occupant, or let to another for occupancy, any commercial structure or commercial unit, for the purpose of commercial activity therein, which does not comply with the following requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 310, Ch. XIII, 5-8-78 ; Ord. No. 806, Ch. XIII, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-137. - Toilet facilities. 
(a)  oilet facilities, in toilet rooms separate for each sex, shall be provided in all places of employment in accordance with the following table, per CONN-OSHA regulations. The number of facilities to be provided for each sex shall be based on the number of employees of that sex for whom the facilities are furnished. Where toilet rooms will be occupied by no more than one (1) person at a time, can be locked from the inside, and contain no more than one (1) water closet, separate toilet rooms for each sex need not be provided. Where such single occupancy rooms have more than one (1) toilet facility, only one (1) such facility in each toilet room shall be counted for the purpose of the table. Lavatory facilities shall be provided in accordance with the following table, and shall be in the same toilet rooms provided for water closets: 
Number of 
Employees Minimum Number 
of Water 
Closets/Lavatories 1 to 15 1 16 to 35 2 36 to 55 3 56 to 80 4 81 to 110 5 111 to 150 6 over 150 1 additional fixture of each type for each additional 40 employees  
(b)  All water closets and lavatory sinks shall be in good working condition and properly connected to a water supply system which is approved by the appropriate authority and which provides an adequate amount of running water under pressure so as to cause flush water closets to operate properly and an adequate amount of heated and unheated running water under pressure for lavatory sinks. Water closets and lavatory sinks shall be properly connected to a sewer or septic system which is approved by the appropriate authority. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 12.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 12.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-138. - Forced air ventilation. 
    Every commercial structure or commercial unit shall have a system of forced air ventilation providing fresh air at a rate of not less than two (2) cubic feet per minute per square foot of floor area, except where there are supplied windows or some other device affording adequate ventilation in accordance with the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 13.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 13.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-139. - Electrical service, outlets and fixtures. 
    Every commercial structure or commercial unit and all public and common areas shall be equipped with electric service, outlets, and fixtures which shall be properly installed, shall be maintained in good and safe working condition, and shall be connected to the source of electric power in a manner prescribed by the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code and in accordance with the rules, regulations and ordinances of the City of Shelton. The capacity of such services and the number of outlets and fixtures shall be as follows: 
(1)  Commercial structures or units shall have an electric service and outlets or fixtures capable of providing at least three (3) watts per square foot or floor area. 
(2)  Every water closet, bathroom, furnace room and public hall shall contain at least one (1) supplied ceiling or wall type electric light fixture. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 13.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 13.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-140. - Adequate light. 
    Every commercial structure, commercial unit, public hall or stairway, shall be adequately lighted when open to the public so as to provide at least six (6) footcandles of light at the tread or floor level. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 13.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 13.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-141. - Water closet compartments. 
    Every water closet compartment shall comply with the light and ventilation requirement for dwellings and dwelling units contained in section 8-80 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 13.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 13.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-142. - Exterior property areas to be clean, sanitary. 
    All exterior property areas shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition free from any accumulation of garbage, rubbish and other debris. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-143. - Premises to be properly graded. 
    All premises shall be graded and maintained as to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon, or within any building or structure located thereon. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-144. - Rodentproofing required of foundation walls, roof. 
    Every foundation, wall, roof and all other interior or exterior surfaces shall be maintained in a workmanlike state of maintenance and repair and shall be kept in such condition to exclude rodents. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-145. - Foundation. 
    The foundation elements shall adequately support the building at all points. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-146. - Exterior walls. 
    Every exterior wall shall be free of holes, breaks, loose or rotting boards or timbers, and any other conditions which might admit rain or dampness to the interior portions of the walls, or to the occupied spaces of the building. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.05, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-147. - Roof requirements. 
    The roof shall be structurally sound, tight and have no defects which might admit rain, and roof drainage shall be adequate to prevent rain water form causing dampness in the wall ors interior portion of the building. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.06, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.06, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-148. - Floor requirements. 
    Every floor shall be reasonably weathertight, watertight, and dampfree, and shall be kept structurally sound and in good repair. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.07, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.07, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-149. - Safety requirements for stairs, porches, railings and other exit facilities. 
    Stairs, porches, railings and other exit facilities shall be adequate for safety as provided by the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code, and shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Every flight of stairs which is more than two (2) risers high shall have handrails which shall be located as required by the building code. 
(2)  Every porch which is more than three (3) feet higher than the adjacent area shall have handrails and balustrades or other approved protection so located and of such design as required by the building code. 
(3)  Every handrail and balustrade shall be firmly fastened and shall be maintained in good condition. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.08, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.08, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-150. - Windows, exterior doors, hatchway requirements. 
    Every window, exterior door and basement hatchway or similar devices shall be rodentproof and reasonably watertight, and shall be kept in sound working condition and good repair. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.09, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.09, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-151. - Window sashes to have glass panes or approved substitute. 
    Every window sash shall be supplied with glass window panes or an approved substitute. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.10, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.10, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-152. - Rodentproofing required for ground level windows, openings. 
    Every window located at or near ground level or intended to be used for ventilation, and every other opening located at or near ground level which might provide entry for rodents, shall be supplied with adequate gauge screen or such other device as will effectively prevent their entrance. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.11, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.11, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-153. - Flaking, peeling paint prohibited. 
    All walls, ceilings, exterior woodwork, doors and windows shall be kept free of flaking, peeling or loose paint. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.12, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.12, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-154. - Paint requirements. 
    Paint used after the effective date of this chapter on walls and ceilings and other interior portions of structure shall comply with the standards in section 8-93. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.13, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.13, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-155. - Accessory structures to be rodentproof. 
    Every accessory structure shall be rodent proof and maintained so as to prevent rodent harborage. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.14, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.14, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-156. - Structural parts of units to be safe; capable of supporting normal loads. 
    Every foundation, roof, floor, exterior and interior wall, ceiling, inside and outside stair, every porch, and every appurtenance, thereto, shall be safe to use and capable of supporting the loads that normal use may cause to be placed thereon, and shall be kept in sound condition and good repair. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.15, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.15, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-157. - Water closet compartment; bathroom floor surface. 
    Every water closet compartment, bathroom and kitchen floor surface shall be constructed and maintained so as to be reasonably impervious to water, and so permitting such floor to be easily kept in clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.16, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.16, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-158. - Supplied facilities; safe and effective. 
    Every plumbing fixture and pipe, every chimney, flue and smoke pipe, and every other facility, piece of equipment or utility which is present in a commercial unit, or which is required under this chapter shall be constructed and installed in conformance with the applicable local or state codes, and shall be maintained in satisfactory working condition. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.17, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.17, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-159. - Plumbing fixtures. 
    Every plumbing fixture, and water and waste pipe, shall be properly installed and maintained in good sanitary working condition. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.18, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.18, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-160. - Removal, discontinuance of service facilities or utilities. 
    No owner, operator, or occupant shall cause any service, facility, equipment or utility, which is required under this chapter, to be removed from or shut off from, or discontinued for any occupied unit let or occupied by him except for such temporary interruption as may be necessary while actual repairs or alterations are in process, or during temporary emergencies when discontinuance of service is approved by the appropriate authority. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.19, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.19, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-161. - Fire protection. 
    All construction and materials, ways and means of egress, and all installation and use of equipment shall conform to applicable state and local laws dealing with fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 14.20, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 14.20, 4-12-07) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 8-162. - Ceiling height. 
    All of the floor area shall have a ceiling height of no less than seven (7) feet, four (4) inches. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 15.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 15.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-163. - Use of space below grade. 
    No space, located totally or partially below grade, shall be used as a commercial structure or commercial unit unless: 
(1)  The floor, and those portions of the walls below grade, are of waterproof and dampproof construction. 
(2)  If windows are located below grade, they shall be constructed in a properly drained window well whose ground area shall be equal to, or greater than, the area of the window opening; the bottom of the window shall be below the top of the impervious masonry construction under this window; the minimum horizontal projections of the bottom of the window well shall be equal to, or greater than, the vertical dimension of this window opening, and no part of the window well opposite this window shall protrude above a line projected at a forty-five (45) degree angle from the bottom of the window opening at right angles to the outer wall. 
(3)  Ventilation in below grade areas shall be equal to at least the minimum, as required under section 8-138 of this chapter. 
(4)  There are no pipes or other obstructions less than six (6) feet, eight (8) inches, above the floor level which interferes with the normal use of the area. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 15.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 15.02, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-164-8-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 8-170. - Appointment of code enforcement officer. 
    The code enforcement officer shall be appointed by the mayor or his designated representative on the basis of merit and shall have all the qualifications, training, education and experience as outlined in the position classification plan of the City of Shelton. 
(Ord. No. 310, Ch. XVI, 5-8-78 ; Ord. No. 806, Ch. XVI, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-171. - Notice of violations. 
(a)  Whenever the enforcing officer finds that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, he shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person or person responsible therefore, as hereinafter provided: 
(1)  Be put in writing; 
(2)  Set forth the alleged violation or violations of this chapter, or of the rules and regulations pursuant thereto, and describe the premises where the violation is alleged to exists or to have been committed; 
(3)  Specify a reasonable time for the correction of any violation alleged. Such time shall not exceed thirty (30) calendar days. The code enforcement officer and the building official may jointly extend this requirement an additional thirty (30) days. Any extension beyond such point must be requested to the housing code board of appeals within twelve (12) days of the last extension; 
(4)  Be served upon the owner or his agent, or the occupant, as the case may require; provided that such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such owner or agent, or upon such occupant, if a copy thereof is sent by registered or certified mail to his last known address; about the premises affected by the notice; or if he is served with such notice by any other method authorized or required under the laws of this state; 
(5)  Inform the owner, occupant or person in charge that any evidence of a violation of any provisions of this chapter, or any regulation pursuant thereto, may form the basis of criminal prosecution; 
(6)  Inform the owner, occupant or person in charge of his right to appeal said notice to the housing code board of appeals in accordance with section 8-192. 
(b)  After the period of time provided for in subsection (a)(3) above, the code enforcement office shall reinspect the premises described in the notice. If the violation still exists, then a copy of said notice shall be put on the land records of the City of Shelton and indexed by the clerk in the grantor index under the name of the then owner of the property. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 16.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 16.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-172. - Court order required upon refusal to allow inspection. 
    In the event consent to reinspection is refused, and where the code enforcement officer has reasonable grounds to believe that a violation of any provision of this chapter or any regulation pursuant thereto has occurred, or is occurring, he shall apply to the appropriate court, or any judge thereof, for an order directing the owner, operator or occupant of the premises to permit him to make such inspection. Upon procurement of a duly issued order, the code enforcement officer is hereby authorized to enter, inspect, examine and survey the described premises, for the purposes of determining whether there has been compliance with the notice of violation. In the event of refusal to obey such order, the permit for the occupancy of such premises shall be revoked and the owner, operator or occupant shall be subject to the penalties as detailed in article X of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 16.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 16.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-173. - Code enforcement officer to have exclusive responsibility of inspections, orders. 
    Inspection of premises and the issuing of orders in connection therewith under the provisions of this chapter shall be the exclusive responsibility of the code enforcement officer of the City of Shelton. Wherever, in the opinion of the code enforcement officer it is necessary or desirable to have inspections or any condition by any other department or official, he shall arrange for this to be done in such a manner that the owners or occupants of buildings shall not be subjected to visits by numerous inspectors nor to multiple or conflicting orders. No order for correction of any violation under this code shall be issued without the approval of the code enforcement officer and it shall be the responsibility of that official before issuing any such order to determine that it has notified, in writing, any other city department or official of the City of Shelton who have a concern with any matter involved on the case in question. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 16.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 745, 10-12-00; Ord. No. 806, § 16.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-174. - Emergency orders; appeal; penalty for failure to comply. 
    Whenever, in the judgment of the code enforcement officer, an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, welfare or safety, he may forthwith and without notice or hearing, cause to be issued and served, an order reciting the existence of the emergency and requiring such action as he deems necessary to eliminate it. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, such order shall become effective immediately. Any person to whom such order is directed shall comply forthwith provided, however, such order may be appealed to the code enforcement officer for a stay not to exceed five (5) days, within which period, the code enforcement officer, for good cause shown, may modify or revoke such order. Any individual who fails to comply with said order shall be fined two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) a day for each day of failure to comply. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 16.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 16.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-175. - Housing code enforcement officer to keep records of orders; daily log. 
    The code enforcement officer shall keep records of all orders issued and a daily log of his enforcement activities for a period of at least three (3) years after the date of said order(s) or activities. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 16.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 16.05, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-176-8-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HEARINGS AND APPEALS 

Sec. 8-186. - Housing code board of appeals-Created; composition; terms of regular members. 
    There is hereby created a housing code board of appeals, which shall consist of five (5) electors of the City of Shelton, appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of the board of aldermen. No more than three (3) members of said board shall be from the same political party. Each member so appointed shall serve for a term of five (5) years, except that of those appointed immediately following passage of this code; one (1) member shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year, one (1) member shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years, one (1) member shall be appointed for term of five (5) years. Upon expiration of terms of office, the mayor shall make new appointments, subject to the approval of the board of aldermen, each for a term of five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.01, 4-12-07) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-41 et seq. 
Sec. 8-187. - Same-Alternate members appointed; terms. 
    The mayor, with the approval of the board of aldermen, shall also appoint three (3) alternate members of the housing code board of appeals for the term of five (5) years; however, no more than two (2) members shall be from the same political party. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-188. - Same-Vacancies. 
    If any vacancy shall occur on the housing code board of appeals, the mayor, with the approval of the board of aldermen, shall appoint one (1) of the alternate members of said board to serve for the remainder of the unexpired term of office; provided, however, said member appointed shall be a representative of the same political party as the member he replaced. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-189. - Same-Officers; bylaws. 
    The housing code board of appeals shall meet annually to nominate and elect, by majority vote, a chairman and secretary of said board. Said board shall prepare and adopt a set of bylaws to govern its affairs by affirmative vote of at least four (4) members of said board and may amend said by-laws in the same manner. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-190. - Same-Conflict of interest prohibited. 
    No member of the housing code board of appeals shall participate as a member of the board in the hearing on an appeal involving premises in which he has an interest direct or indirect. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.06, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.06, 4-12-07) 
Charter reference- Conflicts of interest, § 9.7. 
Sec. 8-191. - Responsibilities of building official. 
    The building official shall be responsible for coordinating the housing and commercial properties code enforcement program for the City of Shelton, in conjunction with the code enforcement officer in charge of enforcing this Code, shall be under the director of inspection and compliance, who also shall be responsible for making recommendations to the board of aldermen for any changes or amendments to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.05 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-192. - Notice of violation; hearing; filing of petition; notice. 
    Any person aggrieved by a notice of the code enforcement officer issued in connection with any inspection, examination or survey pursuant thereto, may request, and shall be granted, a hearing on the matter before the housing code board of appeals, provided that such person shall file in the office of the housing code board of appeals a written petition requesting such a hearing and setting forth the grounds therefore within five (5) normal working days after the notice of the code enforcement office was served upon such person. Said board shall meet upon notice of the chairman following receipt of an appeal, not later than six (6) normal working days after such receipt, to hear the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.07, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.07, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-193. - Hearings to be public. 
    All hearings shall be open to the pubic and the appellant, his representative, the code enforcement officer and any other person whose interests may be affected by the matter on appeal, shall be given the opportunity to be heard. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.08, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.08, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-194. - Powers of housing code board of appeals. 
    The housing code board of appeals is hereby authorized to administer oaths and affirmations to witnesses at such hearings to request the subpoena witnesses and documents employed in such hearings. Subpoenas shall be served in the method prescribed by the rules of the courts of the State of Connecticut. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.09, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.09, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-195. - Notices of code enforcement officer under appeal to be suspended. 
    Any notice of the code enforcement officer which is under appeal shall be suspended. The board's decision, confirming, modifying or revoking such notice shall then prevail. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.10, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.10, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-196. - Variances. 
    All variances granted by the board which requires rehabilitative work, must specify a reasonable amount of time for the completion of such work. If, after having begun rehabilitation, the appellant feels he cannot meet the specified time limit, he may request and shall be granted another hearing before the board, for an extension of the time limit. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.11, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.11, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-197. - Timely decisions. 
    The board shall render a decision on an appeal not later than five (5) working days following the day of the hearing thereon, and shall require a minimum of four (4) concurring votes. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.12, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.12, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-198. - Proceedings to be reduced at writing. 
    All proceedings at such hearings, including the findings and decision of the board of appeals, shall be reduced to writing and entered as a matter of public record in the office of the code enforcement officer within five (5) working days following the day of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.13, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.13, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-199. - Judicial review of decision. 
    Any person aggrieved by any ruling of the Shelton Housing Code Board of Appeals may appeal to a court of common pleas by complaint returnable within sixty (60) days of the board's decision. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 17.14, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 17.14, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-200-8-205. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - FEES 

Sec. 8-206. - Schedule. 
    The fees for the inspection of and the issuance of certificates of occupancy and/or permits for dwellings, dwelling units, rooming house, premises, commercial structures and commercial units, shall be payable at the time application for same is made and shall be in accordance with the following schedule:

Add five dollars ($5.00) for each additional six (6) rooms/rooming units or fraction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 310, Ch. XIX, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, Ch. XIX, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-207-8-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 8-211. - Adopted. 
    Any person who shall willfully violate any standard, requirement or provision of this chapter or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant hereto, or who shall willfully refuse or fail to obey any order properly issued by the code enforcement officer shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or by imprisonment for not more than one (1) year, or both. Each day's failure or refusal to comply shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 310, Ch. XX, 5-8-78) 
Secs. 8-212-8-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - CONDEMNATION 

Sec. 8-216. - Defects requiring condemnation; placarding. 
(a)  The designation of structures, or units thereof as unfit for human habitation/occupancy/use and the procedure for the condemnation and placarding of such, shall be carried out in accordance with the following requirements. 
(b)  Any structure, or unit thereof, which shall be found to have any of the following defects, shall be condemned as unfit for human habitation/occupancy/use and shall be so designated and placarded by the code enforcement officer: 
(1)  One which is so damaged, decayed or dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe, or vermin-infested that it creates a serious hazard to the health or safety of the occupants or of the public. 
(2)  One which lacks illumination, ventilation, heat or sanitation facilities adequate to protect the health or safety of the occupants or of the public. 
(3)  One which, because of its general condition or location, is unsanitary or otherwise dangerous to the health or safety of the occupants or of the public. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 21.01, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 21.01, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-217. - Condemned building to be vacated. 
    Any structure, or unit thereof, condemned as for human habitation/occupancy/use, and so designated and placarded by the code enforcement officer, shall be vacated within thirty (30) days, except that dwellings, rooming houses, and hotels or units thereof, shall be vacated within ten (10) days. Every reasonable effort shall be made by city agencies to relocated families or households of such units. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 21.02, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 21.02, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-218. - Approval to reoccupy condemned building required. 
    No structure or unit thereof, that has been condemned and placarded as unfit for human habitation/occupancy/use shall be again used for such purpose until written approval is secured from, and said placard is removed by, or with the permission of, the code enforcement officer. Following reinspection of the structure, or unit thereof, in question, the code enforcement officer shall permit removal of such placard by the owner, occupant or person in charge of the structure or unit thereof, whenever the defect or defects upon which the placarding action was based, have been eliminated. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 21.03, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 21.03, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-219. - Defacing or removing placard prohibited. 
    No person shall willfully deface or remove the placard from any structure, or unit thereof, which has been condemned as unfit for human habitation/occupancy/use, and placarded as such, except when such action has been authorized by the code enforcement officer as provided for in section 8-218 above. Whoever violates this provision shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. No. 310, § 21.04, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 21.04, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-220. - Hearing on condemnation notice or order. 
    Any person aggrieved by any order involving the placarding of a structure, or unit thereof, may request and shall be granted a hearing under the conditions specified in section 8-192 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 21.05, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 21.05, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-221. - Demolishing of building authorized. 
    Where no corrective action is taken by the owner or person in charge of a structure, or unit thereof, designated as unfit for human habitation/occupancy/use, within thirty (30) days following the placarding action, and when no hearing is pending, the code enforcement officer may order the structure in violation to be demolished in accordance with the procedures specified in the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 21.06, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 21.06, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-222. - Subsequent transferees of condemned structures. 
    All subsequent transferees of the condemned structure, or unit thereof, shall be deemed to have notice of the continuing existence of the violations alleged; and said transferees shall be liable to all penalties and procedures provided by this chapter and by the applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto to the same degree as was their transferor. 
(Ord. No. 310, § 21.07, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, § 2.07 4-12-07) 
Sec. 8-223. - Commercial structures. 
    The legal procedure for condemnation of commercial structures is under jurisdiction of the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 310, Ch. XXII, 5-8-78; Ord. No. 806, Ch. XXII, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 8-224-8-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - HOUSING PARTNERSHIP 

Sec. 8-251. - Created. 
(a)  Generally. There is hereby created the Shelton Housing Partnership, appointed by the chief elected official of the municipality, subject to the approval of the board of aldermen. The partnership shall consist of the following members: 
(1)  The chief elected official of the City of Shelton; 
(2)  Representatives of the planning and zoning commission, inland/wetlands commission, housing authority, board of aldermen and any local community development agency, not to exceed six (6) in number; 
(3)  Representatives of the local business community, such as local bankers, realtors and developers, not to exceed ten (10) in number; 
(4)  Representatives of public interest groups, such as housing advocates, members of the clergy, members of the local civic groups and representatives of local nonprofit corporations, not to exceed ten (10) in number; and 
(5)  Local urban planning, land use and housing professionals not to exceed four (4) in number. 
(b)  Approval of representatives. A breakdown of names representing the various constituents as established under subsection (a) shall be furnished by the mayor's office and approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 567, §§ 1, 4, 5-11-89) 
Sec. 8-252. - Responsibilities of city, in order to receive initial designation under Connecticut Housing Partnership Program. 
    The responsibilities of the city, in order to receive initial designation under the Connecticut Housing Partnership Program, shall include the following: 
(1)  Submit evidence to the commissioner of housing that the Shelton Housing Partnership has been formed in accordance with P.A. 88-305; and 
(2)  Submit evidence to the commissioner of housing that sufficient local resources have been committed to the Shelton Housing Partnership. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 2, 5-11-89) 
Sec. 8-253. - Duties of housing partnership in order to receive development designation under Connecticut Housing Partnership Program. 
    The duties of the Shelton Housing Partnership, in order to receive development designation under the Connecticut Housing Partnership Program, shall include the following: 
(1)  To examine and identify housing needs and opportunities in the community; 
(2)  To explore the availability of any state, municipal or other land that is suitable for the development of affordable housing; 
(3)  To review applicable zoning regulations to determine whether such zoning regulations restrict the development of affordable housing in the community; 
(4)  To identify any necessary changes to such regulations; 
(5)  To establish priorities and develop a long range plan to meet identified housing needs in the community consistent with regional housing needs; 
(6)  To establish procedures for the development of a written proposal to achieve such priorities in accordance with the plan; and 
(7)  To start an activity, development or project designed to create additional affordable housing in the city. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 3, 5-11-89) 
Sec. 8-254. - No conflict with state or federal statutes. 
    This article shall not be construed so as to conflict with any state or federal statute, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 5, 5-11-89) 
Sec. 8-255. - Expenses. 
    No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the municipality in carrying out any partnership activities authorized by this article without prior approval by the legislative body nor shall any person have any right to find the municipality by contract, agreement or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the legislative body. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 6, 5-11-89) 
Chapter 9 - LICENSES, PERMITS AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Building permits, § 3-26 et seq.; development permit, § 5-24; rooming houses, hotels and motel operators permit, § 8-52; rooming houses, hotels and motel licenses, § 8-53 et seq.; massage establishment, § 9-43 et seq.; amusement center license, § 9-82 et seq.; boat launching permit, § 11-36; excavation permit required, § 14-51; termination of excavation permit, § 14-64; public sewer connection required, § 17-42; state permit required for large domestic discharges, § 17-88. 
State Law reference- Auctioneers' licenses, G.S. §§ 21-1-21-5; itinerant vendors' licenses, G.S. §§ 21-27-21-35; junk dealers' licenses, G.S. §§ 21-9-21-14; package store permits, G.S. § 30-20; pawnbrokers, G.S. §§ 21-39-21-47; peddlers, G.S. §§ 21-36-21-38; regulation of vending machines, G.S. § 21a-43. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Peddlers and street vendors. 
(a)  License required. No person shall peddle any kind of goods, wares, or merchandise about the streets, from house to house, or upon any public street, park, or common within the city without having a license therefor from the chief of police granted in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Application for license. No person shall receive a peddler's license unless he shall, before the time when he desires his license to be granted, make application in writing for such license over his own signature to the chief of police, in which application shall be truly stated: 
(1)  The name and residence of the applicant; 
(2)  The kind of goods, wares, or merchandise desired to be peddled; 
(3)  The length of time for which the license is desired, which application shall be kept on file in the office of the chief of police. 
(c)  License fee. A fee shall be paid by an applicant for a peddler's license to the chief of police in a sum not to exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) before the issue of the peddler's license. 
(d)  Term of license. No peddler's license shall be granted for a longer term than one (1) year. 
(e)  Expiration date of license. All peddlers' licenses shall expire on the first Monday of the March next succeeding the granting of the license. 
(f)  Refusal to show license. Every person licensed under the provisions of this section who shall refuse or neglect to exhibit and show such license on the demand of any officer of the city shall be subject to the penalty provided in subsection (h) of this section. 
(g)  Exemptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale within the city of provisions or farmers' produce, nor shall the same apply to or prevent the taking of orders by resident or nonresident merchants for goods, wares or merchandise, to be afterwards filled and delivered by them, their clerks or agents. 
(h)  Penalty. Every person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and each sale or attempt to sell shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, § 8.1; Ord. No. 578, § 14, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 684, § 1(a)-(c), 4-13-95; Ord. No. 812, 4-12-07) 
State Law reference- Hawkers and peddlers, G.S. § 21-36 et seq.; ordinances authorized, G.S. § 21-37. 
Sec. 9-2. - Bazaars and raffles. 
    The city adopts the provisions of sections 7-170 through 7-186; inclusive, of the general statutes, which sections prescribe the terms and conditions of the adoption of the bazaar and raffle law and sponsorship of or participation in them. 
(Ord. No. 568, 5-11-89) 
Secs. 9-3-9-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 578 repealed Ord. No. 442, adopted April 14, 1983, from which former Art. II, §§ 9-16-9-27, solicitors and canvassers, derived. Sections 1-13 of Ord. No. 578 were included as a new Art. II at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Hawkers and peddlers, G.S. § 21-36 et seq.; ordinances authorized, G.S. § 21-37. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-16. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words as used herein shall be considered to have the meaning herein ascribed thereto: 
    Registered solicitor shall mean and include any person who has obtained a valid certificate of registration as hereinafter provided, which certificate is in the possession of the solicitor or his or her person while engaged in soliciting. 
    Residence shall mean and include every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one (1) or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. 
    Soliciting shall mean and include any one (1) or more of the following activities while calling at residences without the previous consent of the occupant: 
(a)  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services, of any kind, character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever; 
(b)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or publication; 
(c)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publication; 
(d)  Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project; or 
(e)  Solicitation as defined therein shall not include telephone communication. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 1, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 1, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-17. - Notice regulating soliciting. 
    Every person desiring to secure the protection provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this article, shall comply with the following directions, to wit: Notice of the determination by the occupant of giving invitation to solicitors, or the refusal of invitation to solicitors, to any residence, shall be given in the manner following: 
(1)  A sign or notice approximately three (3) inches by four (4) inches in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words, as follows: 
"Only Solicitors Registered in Shelton Invited" 
or 
"No Solicitors Invited" 
(2)  The letters shall be at least one-third ( 1/3 ) inch in height. For the purpose of uniformity a sign may be provided by the chief of police to persons requesting, at the cost thereof. 
(3)  Such sign so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the information contained thereon. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 9, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 9, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-18. - Duty of solicitors. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the municipality upon which a residence as herein defined is located, to first examine the notice provided for in this article, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on any if the notice states "Only Solicitors Registered in Shelton Invited", then the solicitor not possessing a valid certificate of registration as herein provided shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises, and if the notice states "No Solicitors Invited," then the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
(b)  Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 10, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 10, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-19. - Uninvited soliciting prohibited. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to enter upon any premises and ring the door bell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting as herein defined, in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of section 9-17. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 11, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 11, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-20. - Certificate required to be carried. 
    It shall be the obligation of every person who has obtained a certificate of registration under the terms of this article to carry the certificate upon his person at any time while soliciting within the boundaries of the city. Any such solicitor who gains entrance to any residence or any property shall immediately and peacefully depart therefrom when requested to do so by the occupant. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 8, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 8, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-21. - Time limit on soliciting. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person whether registered under this article or not, to go upon any premises and ring the door bell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting as herein defined, prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. of any weekday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a State or national holiday. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 12, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 12, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-22. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense. Each sale or attempt to sell or contact with a residence in violation of this article shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 14, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 14, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 9-23-9-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION 

Sec. 9-31. - Required. 
    Every person desiring to engage in soliciting as herein defined from persons in residences within this municipality, is hereby required to make written application for a certificate of registration as hereinafter provided. Such certificate shall be carried by the solicitor. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 2, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 2, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-32. - Application. 
(a)  Application for certificate of registration. Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form provided by the municipality. The certificate of registration shall be obtained from the Shelton Police Department. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the application, to wit: 
(1)  Name and address or present place of residence and length of residence at such address; also business address if other than present address; 
(2)  The address of place of residence during the past three (3) years if other than present address; 
(3)  Age of applicant; 
(4)  Physical description of the applicant; 
(5)  Name and address of the person, firm or corporation or association or other entity by whom the applicant is employed or otherwise represents, and the length of time of such employment or representation; 
(6)  The name and address of applicant's employer during the past three (3) years if other than the present employer; 
(7)  A description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of the solicitation in which the applicant will engage; 
(8)  The period of time for which the certificate is applied; 
(9)  The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for certificate under this ordinance, if any; 
(10)  A statement as to whether or not any certificate or registration issued to the applicant under this ordinance has ever been revoked; 
(11)  A statement as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or federal law of the United States; 
(12)  The names of three (3) most recent communities where the applicant has solicited house to house; 
(13)  A description of the proposed method of operation; 
(14)  The signature of applicant; 
(15)  The Social Security number of applicant. 
(b)  All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 3, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 3, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-33. - Investigation of applicant. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a certificate of registration, the chief of police shall cause an investigation of an applicant to be made in such a manner and to such extent as the chief of police deems advisable, and, within ten (10) business days of the filing of the application the chief of police, shall issue the certificate applied for except that no permit shall be issued to an individual who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of this state or of any other state or the federal laws of the United States within five (5) years prior to the date of the application, nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, nor to any person whose prior certificate of registration issued under this article has been revoked. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 4, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 4, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-34. - Fingerprinting. 
    The applicant for a certificate of registration shall be required to submit to fingerprinting by the police department of the municipality in connection with the application for the certificate. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 5, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 5, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-35. - Records to be kept. 
    The chief of police shall cause to be kept in the office of the police department an accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all other information and data pertaining thereto and all certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this article, and of the denial of applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every certificate issued, and any renewal thereof, shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 6, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 6, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-36. - Term; revocation of certificate. 
(a)  Any certificate of registration issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for a period of two (2) years from the date of issuance. Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the chief of police if the holder of the certificate is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police to the holder of the certificate in person or be certified United States mail addressed to his or her residence address set forth in the application. 
(b)  Immediately upon the giving of such notice the certificate of registration shall become null and void. 
(c)  The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date thereof. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 7, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 7, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-37. - Fee. 
    Any person making application for a certificate of registration under the terms of this article shall be required to pay a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 578, § 13, 3-8-90; Ord. No. 812, § 13, 4-12-07) 
Secs. 9-38-9-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MASSAGE PARLORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Massage parlors, G.S. § 19a-92. 

Sec. 9-41. - Policy. 
    It is hereby declared that the business of operating massage establishments as defined herein is a business affecting the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 1, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 1, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-42. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Employee. Any and all persons, other than the masseurs or masseuses, who render any service to the permittee, who have no physical contact with customers and clients. 
    Massage. Any method of pressure on, or friction against, or stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating or stimulating of the external soft parts of the body with the hands or with the aid of any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance with or without any supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils, powders, creams, lotions, ointments, or other similar preparations commonly used in this practice. 
    Massage establishment. Any establishment having a fixed business where any person, firm, association, or corporation engages in or carries on or permits to be engaged in or carried on any of the activities mentioned in section 9-43 of this article. 
    Masseur and masseuse. Any person, who, for any consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of massage as herein defined. 
    Person. Any individual, co-partnership, firm, association, joint stock company, corporation, or combinations of individuals of whatever form or character. 
    Recognized school. Any school or institution of learning which has for its purpose the teaching of the theory, the method, profession or work of massage, which school requires in a resident course of study not less than seventy (70) hours to be given in not more than three (3) calendar months before the student shall be furnished with a diploma or certificate of graduation from such school or institution of learning following the successful completion of such course of study or learning. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 2, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 2, 4-12-07) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 9-43. - Massage establishment permit-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on or permit to be engaged in, conducted, or carried on, in or upon any premises in the City of Shelton, the operation of a massage establishment as herein defined without having first obtained a permit as hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 3, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 3(1), 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-44. - Same-Application; fee; contents. 
(a)  Each applicant for a permit to maintain, operate or conduct a massage establishment shall file an application with the chief of police or his designate and pay a filing fee of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) which shall not be refundable. 
(b)  Any person desiring a massage business permit shall file written application with the police chief on a form to be furnished by the police. 
(c)  The application for a permit to operate a massage establishment shall set forth the exact nature of the massage to be administered, the proposed place of business and facilities therein and the name and address of each applicant. 
(d)  Each applicant shall also furnish information to prove that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age; list the business, occupation or employment of the applicant for three (3) years immediately preceding the date of the application; furnish proof of any previous massage or similar business licensing, the date and place of such license and whether the same has ever been revoked or suspended and if so, the reason therefor; provide data as to any previous criminal convictions except minor traffic violations; and submit to normal procedures of the police department for photographs and fingerprints. 
(Ord. No. 302, §§ 4, 5, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, §§ 4, 5, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-45. - Same-Notice of hearing. 
    When the application is filed for a massage establishment permit under this article, the board of aldermen shall fix the time and place for a public hearing where the applicant may present evidence upon the question for this application. Not less than ten (10) days before the date of such hearing, the board of aldermen shall cause to be posted a notice of such hearing in a conspicuous place on the property in which or on which the proposed massage establishment is to be operated. The applicant shall maintain said notices posted for required number of days. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 9, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 9, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-46. - Same-Facilities prerequisite to issuance. 
(a)  No permit to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued unless an inspection by the director of public health or his authorized representative reveals that the establishment complies with each of the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  Construction of rooms used for toilets, tubs, steam baths and showers shall be waterproofed with approved waterproof materials. 
(2)  Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations. When five (5) or more employees and patrons of different sexes are on the premises at the same time, separate toilet facilities shall be provided. A single water closet per section be provided for each twenty (20) or more employees or patrons of that sex on the premises at any one (1) time. Urinals may be substituted for water closets after one (1) water closet has been provided. Toilets shall be designated as to the sex accommodated therein. 
(3)  Lavatories or wash basins provided with both hot and cold running water should be installed in either the toilet room or vestibule. Lavatories or wash basins shall be provided with soap in a dispenser and with sanitary towels. 
(b)  The director of public health shall certify that the proposed massage establishment complies with all the requirements of this section and shall give or send such certification to the chief of police or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 15, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 15, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-47. - Same-Issuance. 
    The chief of police or his designee may issue a permit within fourteen (14) days following a hearing if all requirements for a massage establishment described in this article are met and may issue a permit to all persons who apply to perform massage services unless he finds: 
(1)  The operation as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not have complied with all the applicable laws, including but not limited to, the building, health, city planning, housing, zoning and fire codes of the City of Shelton. 
(2)  That the applicant and any other person who will be directly engaged in the management and operation of a massage establishment has been convicted of: 
a.  A felony; 
b.  An offense involving sexual misconduct with minors; 
c.  Obscenity, keeping or residing in a house of ill fame, solicitation of a lewd or unlawful act, prostitution or pandering; 
d.  Falsification of application. 
(3)  The applicant has had a massage business, masseur, other similar permit or license denied, revoked or suspended for any of the above causes by the city or any other state or local agency within five (5) years prior to the date of the application. 
(4)  The manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business has not successfully completed a resident course of study or learning of not less than seventy (70) hours from a recognized school where the theory, method, profession, work of massage is taught. 
(5)  Each such establishment shall conform to all rules and regulations contained herein and the state sanitary code as well as to such terms and conditions as the state commissioner of public health or the local director of health finds necessary and proper. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 10, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 10, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-48. - Same-Revocation or suspension. 
(a)  Any permit issued for a massage establishment may be revoked or suspended by the chief of police or his designee, after a public hearing before the board of aldermen, or it is found that the provisions of this article are violated or where the permittee or any employee of the permittee, including a masseur or masseuse, has been convicted of any offense found in section 9-47(1), (2) or (3), and the permittee has actual or constructive knowledge of the violation or conviction, or in any case where the permittee or licensee refused to permit any duly authorized police officer, health inspector or fire officer of the city to inspect the premises or the operation therein. 
(b)  The chief of police or his designee, before revoking or suspending any permit, shall give the permittee at least ten (10) days' written notice of the charges against him and the opportunity for a public hearing before the board of aldermen, at which time the permittee may present evidence bearing upon the question. In such cases the charges shall be specific and in writing. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 13, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 13, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-49. - Same-Transfer. 
    No permit shall be transferable except with the written consent of the chief of police or his designate and the approval of the department of public health; provided, however, that upon the death or incapacity of the permittee, the massage establishment may continue in business for a reasonable period of time to allow for an orderly transfer of permit. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 18, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 18, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-50. - Masseur, masseuse permit-Required. 
    No person shall practice massage as a masseur, employee or otherwise, unless he has obtained a valid and subsisting masseur's permit as hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 3, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 3(2), 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-51. - Same-Application; fee. 
    Any person, including an applicant for a massage establishment permit, who engages in the practice of massages as herein defined shall file an application for a masseur or masseuse permit with the chief of police or his designate upon a form provided by said chief of police and shall pay a filing fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) which shall not be refundable. 
(Ord. No. 302, § 6, 8-8-77; Ord. No. 805, § 6, 4-12-07) 
Sec. 9-52. - Same-Contents of application. 
    The application for a masseur or masseuse permit shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name and residence address. 
(2)  Social Security number. 
(3)  Fingerprints and photograph with necessary information must be taken at time of application. 
(4)  Written evidence that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(5)  The two (2) previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of the applicant. 
(6)  The massage or similar business history and experience, including but not limited to whether or not such person in previously operating in this or another city or state under license or permit has had such license or permit denied, revoked, or suspended and the reason therefore and the business activities or occupations subsequent to such action of denial, suspension or revocation. 
(7)  Business occupation or employment of the applicant for three (3) years immediately preceding date of application. 
(8)  Whether such person has ever been convicted of any crime except minor traffic violations. If any person mentioned in this subsection has been so convicted, a statement must be made giving the place and court in which conviction was obtained and the sentence imposed as a result of such conviction. 
(9)  Name and address of the recognized school attended, the date attended, and a copy of the diploma or certificate of graduation awarded the applicant showing the applicant has successfully completed not less than seventy (70) hours of instruction. 
(10)  Any masseur or masseuse so employed is required to present a certificate from a physician licensed to practice in the State of Connecticut stating that the applicant has been examined and found to be free of any contagious or communicable disease and showing that the examination was conducted within thirty (30) days prior to the submission of the application. 
(11)  Such other information, identification and physical examination of the person deemed necessary by the police chief in order to discover the truth of the matters hereinbefore required to be set forth in the application.
